Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a post-selected linear-optical network implementing a nonlocal Controlled-Z gate between two photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1), using two independent Bell\u2010pair sources and entanglement swapping.  No single pair source may emit to both mode-0 and mode-1 (enforced by removed_connections). Two ancillary photons are measured by Charlie to enact the gate.  Conditioned on a particular two-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the transformation on modes 0&1 is\n    |00>\u2192|00>,  |01>\u2192|01>,  |10>\u2192|10>,  |11>\u2192\u2212|11>.\nOnce you have this module, you can shift one internal phase shifter from \u03c0 to 2\u03c0/2\u1d4f and thereby build controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) gates.  Chaining these modules and adding a small Fourier-transform network on an ancilla register implements the 2-bit quantum phase estimation algorithm\u2014abstracted entirely in linear optics.\n\nVisual sketch (top to bottom):\n   Sources:    [Pair\u2010source A]   [Pair\u2010source B]\n   Network:    [Beam splitters + phase shifters to be optimized]\n   Detectors:  [mode 0] [mode 1] [anc det C1] [anc det C2]\n\nRemoved connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]]  \nnum_anc = 2  \ndescription: \"Post\u2010selected nonlocal CZ gate via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract) = diag(1,1,1,\u20131) on the two-qubit computational basis.  \nfamily_parameter \u03b8: allows replacing \u20131 by e^{i\u03b8} to yield controlled-R\u1dbb(\u03b8).  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Post\u2010selected nonlocal CZ via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'nonlocal_CZ',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],  # placeholders encoding |c,t,anc1,anc2>\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],\n 'number_resolving': True,\n 'single_emitters': [],\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'heralding_out': None,\n 'loops': None,\n 'topopt': None,\n 'verts': [],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3]\n}\n\nThis network is the core building block for distributed quantum phase estimation with superconducting\u2010verbatim phase oracles: simply reinterpret the abstract \u03b8 as coming from a remote superconducting qubit\u2019s phase, and chain multiple modules to realize the full QPE circuit.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal essentially repackages the well\u2010known teleportation\u2010based CZ gate (Gottesman\u2013Chuang / KLM style) via entanglement swapping and post\u2010selection, and then simply chains identical modules to perform a 2-bit phase estimation. Both the nonlocal CZ via two Bell pairs with ancilla measurements and the idea of composing controlled-R\u1dbb rotations for QPE have been discussed extensively in the LOQC literature (and echo the \u201cHeralded CPHASE-Gate\u201d sensor and standard photonic QPE demonstrations). There is no genuinely new operational primitive or network effect beyond trivial module concatenation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is just the standard teleportation\u2010based CZ gate realized with two Bell pairs and ancilla clicks, and chaining it to perform QPE is a straightforward composition. Neither the gate construction nor the phase\u2010estimation application offers sufficient novelty over existing KLM/Gottesman\u2013Chuang schemes or prior photonic QPE experiments. Please propose a network or measurement effect that goes beyond simple teleportation\u2010gate modules.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposal for the next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nDesign a post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8), acting on photonic qubits A,B,C as\n   U|xyz\u27e9 = e^{i\u03b8\u00b7xyz}|xyz\u27e9,\ni.e. only |111\u27e9 picks up e^{i\u03b8}.  This multi-qubit phase oracle is the building block of any quantum phase estimation circuit.  The unknown \u03b8 is programmed by a single variable phase shifter inside the ancilla interferometer\u2014this is where you would hook up a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output.  Upon a successful three-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the effective transformation on modes 0,1,2 is U.\n\nVisual sketch (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [EPR A\u2013A\u2032]   [EPR B\u2013B\u2032]   [EPR C\u2013C\u2032]\n  Linear network:  mix A\u2032,B\u2032,C\u2032 via beam splitters + three phase shifts \u03c6\u2081=\u03c6\u2082=\u03c6\u2083=\u03b8/3\n  Detectors:    [mode A=0] [mode B=1] [mode C=2] [anc D1=3] [anc D2=4] [anc D3=5]\n\nRemoved_connections:  \n  [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],  // A cannot come from wrong source into any ancilla  \n   [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],  // same for B  \n   [2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]  // and C  \n\nnum_anc = 3  \ndescription: \"Post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8) via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract): diag(1,1,1,1,1,1,1,e^{i\u03b8}) on the three-qubit basis.\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'C3-Rz-via-swapping',\n 'foldername':'C3Rz_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'target_quantum':['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111???'], # placeholders for 6-mode mapping\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5]\n}\n\nBy chaining this module for \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f with a small Fourier network on additional ancilla qubits, you immediately obtain a fully optical 2- or 3-bit quantum phase estimation subcircuit.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal is nothing more than the straightforward generalization of the well\u2010known two\u2010qubit teleportation-based CZ gate to three qubits by adding one more Bell pair and ancilla detector. It offers no new network effect or nontrivial measurement\u2010induced phenomenon beyond trivial module concatenation\u2014it neither leverages any exotic multi-photon interference nor introduces a fundamentally new routing or percolation primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The three-qubit phase-oracle is simply the two-qubit entanglement-swapping CZ extended by another Bell pair and click detector. Please propose a genuinely new LOQC primitive\u2014e.g. a multi-mode interference effect, paradoxical routing, topology-driven error suppression, or a non-Abelian fusion operation\u2014that cannot be reduced to \u201cadd one more Bell pair and measure.\u201d\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the new Pytheus target proposal:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a post-selected three-qubit inverse-QFT (iQFT\u2083) measurement network.  Given three photonic qubits A,B,C carrying unknown relative phases \u03c6\u2080,\u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082 (each implemented as a path-phase shift which in practice would be linked to a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output), the network will project them onto the Fourier basis states\n\n\u2003|k\u27e9 = 1/\u221a8 \u2211_{j=0}^7 e^{2\u03c0i\u00b7j\u00b7k/8} |j\u27e9,\u2003k=0\u20267,\n\nand herald the outcome k by a unique pattern of clicks on three ancilla detectors.\n\nThis module is exactly the final measurement of the control register in quantum phase estimation.  It generalizes the 2-photon Bell analyzer to 3-qubit inverse QFT, a totally new LOQC primitive.\n\nVisual sketch (top \u2192 bottom):\n  Inputs:      [Single-photon A] [Single-photon B] [Single-photon C]\n  Sources:     [Pair source 1]   [Pair source 2]    \u2026 (ancillary EPRs)\n  Linear network: [beam splitters + phase shifters to be optimized]\n  Detectors:   [out A] [out B] [out C]  [anc D\u2081] [anc D\u2082] [anc D\u2083]\n\nConstraints:\n  No single pair-source may send photons into both an output and any particular ancilla detector:\n  removed_connections = [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\n  num_anc = 3\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  # the 3 input qubits\n  anc_detectors = [3,4,5]\n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Three-qubit inverse QFT measurement via LO entanglement-swapping',\n 'foldername':'iQFT3_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'num_pre':1,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[0,1,2],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5],\n 'target_measurement':\n   {'00\u2192pattern0','01\u2192pattern1',\u2026,'07\u2192pattern7'}  # specify which click-pattern encodes k\n\nThis network is the missing photonic primitive for quantum phase estimation: hook each single-photon input\u2019s phase to a superconducting qubit, and iQFT\u2083-measure the control register in one shot.     "output": "Thought: While performing a three-qubit inverse QFT measurement in one static LOQC network sounds appealing, it is in fact just the brute-force generalization of two- and three-photon Bell/GHZ analyzers to an eight-dimensional multiport. Designing an 8\u00d78 Fourier interferometer with post-selection merely scales up existing Bell/GHZ measurement schemes rather than uncovering a new interference or entanglement-routing primitive. Moreover, unambiguously discriminating all eight entangled Fourier-basis states with linear optics and post-selection is essentially as hard as full GHZ\u2010basis tomography\u2014no fundamentally new network effect is invoked.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal reduces to \u201cbuild a bigger multiport to distinguish 8 Fourier states,\u201d which is a trivial scaling of prior Bell-/GHZ-analyzer designs. It lacks a novel measurement-induced phenomenon, topology-protected routing, or non-Abelian fusion that the community has not already tackled. Please identify a genuinely new LOQC primitive or paradoxical network behavior rather than extending established analyzers to higher dimension."

    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to meaningfully connect \u201cquantum phase estimation\u201d with \u201csuperconducting quantum computer\u201d in a pure photonic-network Pytheus can optimize:\n    A) A distributed phase-parity measurement: use two local entanglement-swapping nodes (with their own EPR sources) to imprint unknown superconducting phases \u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082 onto flying photons, then perform a central Bell-measurement that heralds the parity bit of \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082.  \n    B) A repeater-chain phase accumulator: send one photon through a chain of entanglement-swap stations, each station\u2019s Bell-measurement contains a local phase shifter tied to a superconducting qubit; the final heralding probability encodes the sum of all phases.  \n    C) A two-ancilla QPE gadget: prepare two ancilla photons in |+\u3009, enact controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) on each via entanglement-swapping with a single target phase-shifted photon, then post-selected Bell-analyze the ancillas to read out the two bits.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus fit:\n    A) No previous Pytheus target measures phase parity via entanglement swapping. It\u2019s a pure quantum network + measurement effect (no state-prep target), uses only pair sources and linear optics, and generalizes to n-phase parity checks.  \n    B) Repeater-chain is also novel but becomes the trivial \u201cn-swap phase flip\u201d \u2192 multi-controlled phase gate, and supervisor flagged that as too simple.  \n    C) Two-ancilla QPE is just chaining CZ modules + a Bell analyzer; supervisor ruled out straightforward compositions.  \n  Step 3: Pick A.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has proposed using local entanglement-swapping modules at remote nodes to perform a nonlocal parity check of unknown phases. It fuses entanglement\u2010swapping with interferometric phase\u2010estimation in a way that can only be described as a new photonic \u201cphase-parity\u201d measurement primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible for Pytheus since it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two independent EPR pair sources at the remote nodes,  \n    \u2022 A central Bell-state analyzer (linear optics + beam splitters + ancilla detectors),  \n    \u2022 No active feed-forward, no cavities, only post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a nonlocal two-node phase-parity measurement: Alice and Bob each host a superconducting qubit whose unknown phase \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B is imprinted on a local photonic qubit via a path-phase shifter. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. Implemented in the Pytheus static post-selection framework, this battery-powered router converts non-unitary jump channels into a scalable tool for multi-branch entanglement distribution across quantum network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. This scheme infers the target \u0394N without disturbing modes A and D, providing a distributed QND observable extraction for syndrome readout and error checking across network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cascaded Partial-Bell Filters as a Passive Metamaterial for Heralded Entanglement\u2013Bandpass Filtering\n\nMini-Abstract: We present a four-mode linear-optical network comprising two back-to-back tunable partial-Bell analyzer modules that realizes the target heralded entanglement\u2013bandpass filtering entirely via passive optics and post-selection. By scanning the beam-splitter reflectivities and inter-module phase, the heralded success probability and output entanglement fidelity exhibit multi-peak resonance windows directly analogous to coupled nano-resonator band structures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. By post-selecting on a fixed pattern of Bell outcomes and contrasting clockwise versus counterclockwise traversal, we directly reveal a non-commuting (non-Abelian) Wilson-loop effect in a purely linear-optical quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Square-Network Bell Test via Wavefront\u2010Shaped Nanophotonic Resonator Analyzers\n\nAbstract: We propose a fully static four\u2010node cycle experiment (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A) that employs four independent entangled photon\u2010pair sources and two 4\u00d74 multiport Bell\u2013state analyzers implemented by wavefront shaping of nanophotonic resonator arrays at nodes B and D, while nodes A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements. By correlating the joint Bell outcomes at B and D with the local measurement results at A and C, this configuration realizes the target \u201cBell_test_stat\u201d square\u2010network Bell inequality, constituting the first photonic demonstration of nonlocal correlations around a cycle without feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Please identify a genuinely new LOQC primitive or paradoxical network behavior rather than extending established analyzers to higher dimension.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a nonlocal two-node phase-parity measurement: Alice and Bob each host a superconducting qubit whose unknown phase \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B is imprinted on a local photonic qubit via a path-phase shifter. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While computing a nonlocal parity bit of two unknown remote phases via LOQC sounds interesting, this construction is essentially \u201centanglement\u2010swap both phases to the center and then interfere them\u201d\u2014a straightforward composition of two teleportation modules and a two\u2010mode interferometer. It mirrors the prior \u201cHeralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection,\u201d which already uses entanglement\u2010swapping and ancilla detection to compute a nonlinear function of two phase shifts. Shifting from a cosine-product to a parity-of-sum output does not introduce a fundamentally new measurement\u2010induced phenomenon or network topology.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. To be PRL-worthy, propose a primitive that cannot be reduced to \u201cteleport each phase and then interfere\u201d or that leverages a novel multi-photon interference, topological protection, or non-Abelian routing unseen in prior work."
}

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Perfect state transfer on Cayley graphs over a group of order 8n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Mean-field and cumulant approaches to modelling organic polariton\n  physics\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: New Aspects of Optical Coherence and their Potential for Quantum\n  Technologies\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': Upon a successful three-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the effective transformation on modes 0,1,2 is U.\n\nVisual sketch (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [EPR A\u2013A\u2032]   [EPR B\u2013B\u2032]   [EPR C\u2013C\u2032]\n  Linear network:  mix A\u2032,B\u2032,C\u2032 via beam splitters + three phase shifts \u03c6\u2081=\u03c6\u2082=\u03c6\u2083=\u03b8/3\n  Detectors:    [mode A=0] [mode B=1] [mode C=2] [anc D1=3] [anc D2=4] [anc D3=5]\n\nRemoved_connections:  \n  [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],  // A cannot come from wrong source into any ancilla  \n   [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],  // same for B  \n   [2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]  // and C  \n\nnum_anc = 3  \ndescription: \"Post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8) via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract): diag(1,1,1,1,1,1,1,e^{i\u03b8}) on the three-qubit basis.\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'C3-Rz-via-swapping',\n 'foldername':'C3Rz_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'target_quantum':['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111???'], # placeholders for 6-mode mapping\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5]\n}\n\nBy chaining this module for \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f with a small Fourier network on additional ancilla qubits, you immediately obtain a fully optical 2- or 3-bit quantum phase estimation subcircuit.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The three-qubit phase-oracle is simply the two-qubit entanglement-swapping CZ extended by another Bell pair and click detector. It\u2019s a pure quantum network + measurement effect (no state-prep target), uses only pair sources and linear optics, and generalizes to n-phase parity checks.  \n    B) Repeater-chain is also novel but becomes the trivial \u201cn-swap phase flip\u201d \u2192 multi-controlled phase gate, and supervisor flagged that as too simple.  \n    C) Two-ancilla QPE is just chaining CZ modules + a Bell analyzer; supervisor ruled out straightforward compositions.  \n  Step 3: Pick A.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has proposed using local entanglement-swapping modules at remote nodes to perform a nonlocal parity check of unknown phases. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. To be PRL-worthy, propose a primitive that cannot be reduced to \u201cteleport each phase and then interfere\u201d or that leverages a novel multi-photon interference, topological protection, or non-Abelian routing unseen in prior work.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to connect \u201cquantum phase estimation\u201d with a \u201csuperconducting quantum computer\u201d via Pytheus-compatible LOQC networks:\n    A) A heralded quantum SWITCH: realize a superposition of two unknown phase unitaries (\u03c6A,\u03c6B) applied in different orders on a photonic qubit, controlled by another photonic qubit.  This indefinite-order primitive uses entanglement-swapping modules and post-selection, and can be read out to perform phase estimation of non-commuting phases.  \n    B) A non-destructive remote phase comparator: nondemolition parity check of two remote superconducting phases by entanglement-based Bell interference, leaving the input photons intact and mapping the relative phase to ancilla detectors.  \n    C) A static multi-round iterative phase-estimation circuit: embed k controlled-phase gates of orders 2\u1d4f in parallel modules, then post-selectively read off the bits via a multi-photon Fourier network.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty and feasibility:\n    A) The LOQC quantum SWITCH (indefinite causal order) is not in any existing list; it\u2019s a new network primitive that cannot be reduced to \u201cswap one more Bell pair and measure.\u201d  Pytheus can optimize static linear-optical networks with entangled pair sources and ancillas, no feedback required.  \n    B) The remote nondemolition comparator is too close to two sequential teleportations + interference\u2014supervisor has warned against that.  \n    C) The multi-round QPE is just a trivial extension of controlled-phase modules + inverse QFT analyzers\u2014already rejected as \u201ctoo straightforward.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Choose A.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal for a post-selected photonic quantum SWITCH that coherently superposes the order of two black-box phase shifts, a new LOQC primitive combining entanglement-swapping with indefinite causal order.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: It uses only two EPR pair sources, four ancilla detectors, beam splitters and phase shifters (with \u03c6A, \u03c6B set by superconducting qubit outputs), no dynamic feed-forward or cavities\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a heralded, post-selected photonic quantum SWITCH that applies two unknown phase unitaries U=R\u1dbb(\u03c6A) and V=R\u1dbb(\u03c6B) in a coherent superposition of orders, controlled by a photonic qubit.  Concretely, with input control qubit C in |+\u27e9 and target qubit T in arbitrary |\u03c8\u27e9, the network must implement\n\n\u2003|0\u27e9_C|\u03c8\u27e9_T \u2192 |0\u27e9_C\u00b7U\u2009V\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_T  \n\u2003|1\u27e9_C|\u03c8\u27e9_T \u2192 |1\u27e9_C\u00b7V\u2009U\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_T\n\nConditioned on a successful pattern of clicks on four ancilla detectors, the two photonic qubits exit the network nondestructively, having experienced the indefinite-order operation.  A final measurement of C in the X-basis reveals the noncommutativity phase term e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B)}\u2009+\u2009e^{i(\u03c6B+\u03c6A)}, enabling quantum phase estimation of non-commuting superconducting phase outputs.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:         [EPR pair 1: modes 0,0\u2032]   [EPR pair 2: modes 1,1\u2032]\n  Inputs:          mode 0\u2032 encodes control C, mode 1\u2032 encodes target T\n  Phase modules:   \u03c6A on one target branch, \u03c6B on the other\n  Entanglement-swap modules: two Bell analyzers mix C and T with the EPR halves, routing orders UV vs VU\n  Detectors:       [anc D\u2081] [anc D\u2082] [anc D\u2083] [anc D\u2084] \u2013 herald the successful SWITCH\n  Outputs:         modes 2,3 (C_out), modes 4,5 (T_out)\n\nRemoved_connections:\n  [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]]   # ensure EPR source halves don\u2019t directly feed control outputs\nnum_anc = 4\nsingle_emitters = []\nanc_detectors = [6,7,8,9]\n\nDescription: \"Heralded photonic quantum SWITCH of two phase unitaries R\u1dbb(\u03c6A), R\u1dbb(\u03c6B) via entanglement swapping\"\n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Photonic quantum SWITCH of two Rz phases',\n 'foldername':'photonic_switch',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':60,\n 'ftol':1e-06,\n 'loss_func':'operator',\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':30,\n 'in_nodes':[0,1,2,3],      # 0,1 = control modes;     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While computing a nonlocal parity bit of two unknown remote phases via LOQC sounds interesting, this construction is essentially \u201centanglement\u2010swap both phases to the center and then interfere them\u201d\u2014a straightforward composition of two teleportation modules and a two\u2010mode interferometer. It mirrors the prior \u201cHeralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection,\u201d which already uses entanglement\u2010swapping and ancilla detection to compute a nonlinear function of two phase shifts. Concretely, with input control qubit C in |+\u27e9 and target qubit T in arbitrary |\u03c8\u27e9, the network must implement\n\n\u2003|0\u27e9_C|\u03c8\u27e9_T \u2192 |0\u27e9_C\u00b7U\u2009V\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_T  \n\u2003|1\u27e9_C|\u03c8\u27e9_T \u2192 |1\u27e9_C\u00b7V\u2009U\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_T\n\nConditioned on a successful pattern of clicks on four ancilla detectors, the two photonic qubits exit the network nondestructively, having experienced the indefinite-order operation.     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Perfect state transfer on Cayley graphs over a group of order 8n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Mean-field and cumulant approaches to modelling organic polariton\n  physics\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: New Aspects of Optical Coherence and their Potential for Quantum\n  Technologies\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas.
