This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': Upon a successful three-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the effective transformation on modes 0,1,2 is U.\n\nVisual sketch (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [EPR A\u2013A\u2032]   [EPR B\u2013B\u2032]   [EPR C\u2013C\u2032]\n  Linear network:  mix A\u2032,B\u2032,C\u2032 via beam splitters + three phase shifts \u03c6\u2081=\u03c6\u2082=\u03c6\u2083=\u03b8/3\n  Detectors:    [mode A=0] [mode B=1] [mode C=2] [anc D1=3] [anc D2=4] [anc D3=5]\n\nRemoved_connections:  \n  [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],  // A cannot come from wrong source into any ancilla  \n   [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],  // same for B  \n   [2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]  // and C  \n\nnum_anc = 3  \ndescription: \"Post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8) via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract): diag(1,1,1,1,1,1,1,e^{i\u03b8}) on the three-qubit basis.\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'C3-Rz-via-swapping',\n 'foldername':'C3Rz_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'target_quantum':['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111???'], # placeholders for 6-mode mapping\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5]\n}\n\nBy chaining this module for \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f with a small Fourier network on additional ancilla qubits, you immediately obtain a fully optical 2- or 3-bit quantum phase estimation subcircuit.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The three-qubit phase-oracle is simply the two-qubit entanglement-swapping CZ extended by another Bell pair and click detector. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; The four click\u2010patterns simultaneously reveal the sum \u03c6A+\u03c6B and the difference \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B (i.e. two bits of phase information in one shot).  \n  B) A \u201cphase\u2010echo repeater\u201d chain where a photonic qubit picks up \u03c6 from a distant superconducting qubit, is entanglement\u2010swapped through two nodes with opposite phase\u2010shifter signs, and the ancilla\u2010heralded output cancels common noise while amplifying the target phase (a new LOQC echo\u2010measurement).  \n  C) A \u201ctwo\u2010branch parity switch\u201d that routes an input photon along two photonic paths conditioned on the unknown superconducting phase, then recombines them by entanglement\u2010swapping with an EPR pair, enabling a nondestructive modulo\u20104 phase check in one heralded click.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n  A) No existing Pytheus target uses a measurement basis that is itself a coherent superposition of two Bell bases. This is a new LOQC primitive that directly outputs two phase\u2010bits. It uses one EPR source + two single\u2010photon sources + static linear optics + post\u2010selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit.  \n  B) The echo repeater is conceptually interesting but ultimately reduces to two sequential swaps plus a phase\u2010difference measurement\u2014too close to standard parity schemes.  \n  C) The modulo\u20104 parity switch is exotic but effectively just a doubled parity\u2010check network; it doesn\u2019t introduce a new interference\u2010based measurement beyond A).\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces a \u201csuperimposed Bell\u2010measurement\u201d LOQC primitive: instead of projecting onto one Bell basis at a time, the device post\u2010selectively implements a coherent superposition of two Bell measurements, extracting both sum\u2010 and difference\u2010phases of two unknown inputs simultaneously. No prior experiment or Pytheus target has realized a measurement whose basis itself is a quantum superposition of different entanglement\u2010swapping bases.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it uses:\n  \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (the input qubits A,B carrying \u03c6A,\u03c6B),\n  \u2022 One probabilistic EPR pair source,\n  \u2022 A static linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and four ancilla detectors,\n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no state\u2010generation target\u2014only a quantum network transformation & measurement post\u2010selection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is your new Pytheus target proposal:\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single post\u2010selected LOQC device that takes two input photons A and B\u2014each has a path\u2010phase shift \u03c6A or \u03c6B programmed by a remote superconducting qubit\u2014and one EPR pair (modes C,D).  The linear\u2010optical network is optimized so that, conditioned on exactly two clicks among the four ancilla detectors, the joint measurement projects A,B onto a superposition of two Bell bases:\n\n  Basis 1: |\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9 = (|00\u27e9\u00b1|11\u27e9)/\u221a2 \n  Basis 2: |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9 = (|01\u27e9\u00b1|10\u27e9)/\u221a2\n\nFour distinct click\u2010patterns (D\u2081&D\u2083, D\u2082&D\u2084, D\u2081&D\u2084, D\u2082&D\u2083) herald respectively:\n  \u2013 even\u2010sum bit: \u27e8\u03a6+|\u2192 \u201csum=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010sum  bit: \u27e8\u03a8+|\u2192 \u201csum=\u03c0\u201d  \n  \u2013 even\u2010diff bit:\u27e8\u03a6\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010diff  bit:\u27e8\u03a8\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=\u03c0\u201d\n\nThus in one heralded measurement we learn two bits: the parity of \u03c6A+\u03c6B and of \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B, implementing a two\u2010bit QPE subroutine on non\u2010commuting phase inputs.  \n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Inputs:      [Single\u2010photon A (mode 0)] \u2013 phase \u03c6A  \n               [Single\u2010photon B (mode 1)] \u2013 phase \u03c6B  \n  Source:      [EPR pair source: modes 2,3]  \n  Network:     [Beam splitters + fixed \u03c0/2 and 0 phases to be optimized]  \n  Detectors:   [anc D\u2081=4] [anc D\u2082=5] [anc D\u2083=6] [anc D\u2084=7]\n\nConstraints:\n  \u2013 removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]]  \n    (ensure no direct EPR half \u2192 input detours)  \n  \u2013 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2013 single_emitters = [0,1]  \n  \u2013 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Superimposed Bell\u2010measurement for sum/diff phase bits',\n 'foldername':'super-BSM_phaseQPE',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'single_emitters':[0,1],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]],\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5,6,7],\n 'target_quantum':[\n   # (mode0,mode1,mode2,mode3)->which two ancilla click pattern\n   '00?? -> D1&D3','11?? -> D2&D4','01?? -> D1&D4','10?? -> D2&D3'\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 Introduces a brand\u2010new LOQC primitive\u2014coherent superposition of Bell\u2010measurement bases\u2014rather than toggling between them.  \n  \u2022 Yields two bits of phase\u2010estimation in one shot, fusing entanglement\u2010swapping with superposed measurement\u2010bases.  \n  \u2022 Directly links to superconducting qubits via programmable \u03c6A,\u03c6B at the input.  \n  \u2022 Generalizes to N inputs by constructing superpositions of multiple entanglement\u2010swap bases to extract arbitrary linear combinations of phases."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Square-Network Bell Test via Wavefront\u2010Shaped Nanophotonic Resonator Analyzers\n\nAbstract: We propose a fully static four\u2010node cycle experiment (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A) that employs four independent entangled photon\u2010pair sources and two 4\u00d74 multiport Bell\u2013state analyzers implemented by wavefront shaping of nanophotonic resonator arrays at nodes B and D, while nodes A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements. By correlating the joint Bell outcomes at B and D with the local measurement results at A and C, this configuration realizes the target \u201cBell_test_stat\u201d square\u2010network Bell inequality, constituting the first photonic demonstration of nonlocal correlations around a cycle without feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to meaningfully connect \u201cquantum phase estimation\u201d with \u201csuperconducting quantum computer\u201d in a pure photonic-network Pytheus can optimize:\n    A) A distributed phase-parity measurement: use two local entanglement-swapping nodes (with their own EPR sources) to imprint unknown superconducting phases \u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082 onto flying photons, then perform a central Bell-measurement that heralds the parity bit of \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082.  \n    B) A repeater-chain phase accumulator: send one photon through a chain of entanglement-swap stations, each station\u2019s Bell-measurement contains a local phase shifter tied to a superconducting qubit; the final heralding probability encodes the sum of all phases.  \n    C) A two-ancilla QPE gadget: prepare two ancilla photons in |+\u3009, enact controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) on each via entanglement-swapping with a single target phase-shifted photon, then post-selected Bell-analyze the ancillas to read out the two bits.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus fit:\n    A) No previous Pytheus target measures phase parity via entanglement swapping. It\u2019s a pure quantum network + measurement effect (no state-prep target), uses only pair sources and linear optics, and generalizes to n-phase parity checks.  \n    B) Repeater-chain is also novel but becomes the trivial \u201cn-swap phase flip\u201d \u2192 multi-controlled phase gate, and supervisor flagged that as too simple.  \n    C) Two-ancilla QPE is just chaining CZ modules + a Bell analyzer; supervisor ruled out straightforward compositions.  \n  Step 3: Pick A.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has proposed using local entanglement-swapping modules at remote nodes to perform a nonlocal parity check of unknown phases. It fuses entanglement\u2010swapping with interferometric phase\u2010estimation in a way that can only be described as a new photonic \u201cphase-parity\u201d measurement primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible for Pytheus since it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two independent EPR pair sources at the remote nodes,  \n    \u2022 A central Bell-state analyzer (linear optics + beam splitters + ancilla detectors),  \n    \u2022 No active feed-forward, no cavities, only post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a nonlocal two-node phase-parity measurement: Alice and Bob each host a superconducting qubit whose unknown phase \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B is imprinted on a local photonic qubit via a path-phase shifter. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. The four click\u2010patterns simultaneously reveal the sum \u03c6A+\u03c6B and the difference \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B (i.e. two bits of phase information in one shot).  \n  B) A \u201cphase\u2010echo repeater\u201d chain where a photonic qubit picks up \u03c6 from a distant superconducting qubit, is entanglement\u2010swapped through two nodes with opposite phase\u2010shifter signs, and the ancilla\u2010heralded output cancels common noise while amplifying the target phase (a new LOQC echo\u2010measurement).  \n  C) A \u201ctwo\u2010branch parity switch\u201d that routes an input photon along two photonic paths conditioned on the unknown superconducting phase, then recombines them by entanglement\u2010swapping with an EPR pair, enabling a nondestructive modulo\u20104 phase check in one heralded click.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n  A) No existing Pytheus target uses a measurement basis that is itself a coherent superposition of two Bell bases. This CSWAP is a new routing primitive\u2014rather than teleporting, it conditionally swaps two photonic modes.  Used repeatedly, it routes a target photon through successive phase\u2010oracle modules (\u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f) to build a QPE network by photon routing instead of many controlled\u2010phase gates.\n  B) A \u201ccoherent entanglement\u2010switch\u201d that superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swapping topologies (A\u2013C vs. A\u2013D) in one static network, controlled by a phase \u03c6 from a superconducting device\u2014an indefinite\u2010topology LOQC primitive. This echo network is interesting but essentially cascades standard swaps and parity checks.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty & Pytheus\u2010fit check:\n  A) No Pytheus target so far asked for a post\u2010selected Fredkin gate. A heralded Fredkin is a pure LOQC network transformation, not state generation. It yields a new routing primitive and directly ties into QPE by conditional path selection.\n  B) Too similar to SWITCH experiments, and SWITCH was earlier rejected as \u201cnot novel enough.\u201d\n  C) Reducible to sequential parity\u2010measurements\u2014supervisor wants a new primitive beyond parity checks.\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal for a post\u2010selected LOQC Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate whose control amplitude is a continuous phase \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit. It elevates entanglement swapping from state\u2010creation to photon\u2010routing: a single static network that conditionally swaps two modes based on a tunable phase, a brand\u2010new LOQC primitive never tackled by Pytheus.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:  \n\u2013 Uses only one single\u2010photon emitter (control qubit with phase \u03c6), two probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources (to supply the two target modes plus ancillas), beam splitters and static phase shifters, and four ancilla detectors for heralding.  \n\u2013 No cavities, no active feedback\u2014entirely a post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2013 Output is a two\u2010qubit gate (CSWAP) on abstract qubits A,B controlled by \u03c6; from this module one can build a photon\u2010routing QPE: routing the target photon k times through a \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f phase line by chaining identical Fredkin blocks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nDesign a heralded photonic Fredkin gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) on three abstract qubits C (control), A and B (targets):\n\n  U_CS\u2009WAP\u2009|c,a,b\u27e9 = |c\u27e9\u2297 \n       { |a,b\u27e9      if c=0  \n       { |b,a\u27e9       if c=1  \n\nThe control qubit C is a single photon whose |1\u27e9 amplitude carries a tunable phase \u03c6 (this phase is where you hook up the superconducting qubit). A and B are abstract photonic qubits. On success (a specific four-click pattern on the ancilla detectors), the network effects the CSWAP on modes 0,1,2.\n\nThis Fredkin is a new LOQC routing primitive. By feeding the same target photon through a sequence of such blocks\u2014each with \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f encoded in the control arm\u2014one implements the controlled\u2010U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation entirely by conditional photon routing instead of multiple controlled\u2010phase gates.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n Sources:       [Pair source 1: modes 1\u21944]   [Pair source 2: modes 2\u21945]  \n Emitter:       [Single\u2010photon C in mode 0, phase \u03c6]  \n Network:       [Beam splitters + static phase shifters to be optimized]  \n Detectors:     [mode A_out=3] [mode B_out=6] [anc D1=7] [anc D2=8] [anc D3=9] [anc D4=10]\n\nNodes:\n  input modes = [0 (C), 1 (A), 2 (B)]\n  ancilla detectors = [7,8,9,10]\n  output modes = [3 (A_out),6 (B_out)]\n\nRemoved_connections:\n  [[0,7],[0,8],[0,9],[0,10],  # control C cannot feed directly into any ancilla\n   [1,7],[1,8],                # A cannot directly feed certain ancillas\n   [2,9],[2,10]]               # B cannot directly feed certain ancillas\n\nnum_anc = 4\nsingle_emitters = [0]\nanc_detectors = [7,8,9,10]\n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Heralded photonic Fredkin (CSWAP) via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername':'fredkin_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'ftol':1e-06,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[0],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,7],[0,8],[0,9],[0,10],[1,7],[1,8],[2,9],[2,10]],\n 'anc_detectors':[7,8,9,10],\n 'target_transformation':'CSWAP on modes 0,1,2'}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 A brand\u2010new LOQC primitive: entanglement\u2010swap\u2010based routing (CSWAP) rather than just state creation or Bell analysis.  \n \u2022 Control phase \u03c6 is directly imported from a superconducting qubit, linking superconducting phase\u2010oracles with photonic routing.  \n \u2022 Building block for alternative QPE: by chaining k such Fredkin modules (each with phase \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f) a single target photon collects the high\u2010order phase steps via conditional loops\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward needed.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi\u2010target routing, resource\u2010efficient photon\u2010routing networks, and could inspire topological\u2010photonic routing beyond standard LOQC gates."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While computing a nonlocal parity bit of two unknown remote phases via LOQC sounds interesting, this construction is essentially \u201centanglement\u2010swap both phases to the center and then interfere them\u201d\u2014a straightforward composition of two teleportation modules and a two\u2010mode interferometer. It mirrors the prior \u201cHeralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection,\u201d which already uses entanglement\u2010swapping and ancilla detection to compute a nonlinear function of two phase shifts. Shifting from a cosine-product to a parity-of-sum output does not introduce a fundamentally new measurement\u2010induced phenomenon or network topology.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to meaningfully connect \u201cquantum phase estimation\u201d with \u201csuperconducting quantum computer\u201d in a pure photonic-network Pytheus can optimize:\n    A) A distributed phase-parity measurement: use two local entanglement-swapping nodes (with their own EPR sources) to imprint unknown superconducting phases \u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082 onto flying photons, then perform a central Bell-measurement that heralds the parity bit of \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082.  \n    B) A repeater-chain phase accumulator: send one photon through a chain of entanglement-swap stations, each station\u2019s Bell-measurement contains a local phase shifter tied to a superconducting qubit; the final heralding probability encodes the sum of all phases.  \n    C) A two-ancilla QPE gadget: prepare two ancilla photons in |+\u3009, enact controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) on each via entanglement-swapping with a single target phase-shifted photon, then post-selected Bell-analyze the ancillas to read out the two bits.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus fit:\n    A) No previous Pytheus target measures phase parity via entanglement swapping. It\u2019s a pure quantum network + measurement effect (no state-prep target), uses only pair sources and linear optics, and generalizes to n-phase parity checks.  \n    B) Repeater-chain is also novel but becomes the trivial \u201cn-swap phase flip\u201d \u2192 multi-controlled phase gate, and supervisor flagged that as too simple.  \n    C) Two-ancilla QPE is just chaining CZ modules + a Bell analyzer; supervisor ruled out straightforward compositions.  \n  Step 3: Pick A.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has proposed using local entanglement-swapping modules at remote nodes to perform a nonlocal parity check of unknown phases. It fuses entanglement\u2010swapping with interferometric phase\u2010estimation in a way that can only be described as a new photonic \u201cphase-parity\u201d measurement primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible for Pytheus since it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two independent EPR pair sources at the remote nodes,  \n    \u2022 A central Bell-state analyzer (linear optics + beam splitters + ancilla detectors),  \n    \u2022 No active feed-forward, no cavities, only post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a nonlocal two-node phase-parity measurement: Alice and Bob each host a superconducting qubit whose unknown phase \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B is imprinted on a local photonic qubit via a path-phase shifter. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. Used repeatedly, it routes a target photon through successive phase\u2010oracle modules (\u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f) to build a QPE network by photon routing instead of many controlled\u2010phase gates.\n  B) A \u201ccoherent entanglement\u2010switch\u201d that superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swapping topologies (A\u2013C vs. A\u2013D) in one static network, controlled by a phase \u03c6 from a superconducting device\u2014an indefinite\u2010topology LOQC primitive. It yields a new routing primitive and directly ties into QPE by conditional path selection.\n  B) Too similar to SWITCH experiments, and SWITCH was earlier rejected as \u201cnot novel enough.\u201d\n  C) Reducible to sequential parity\u2010measurements\u2014supervisor wants a new primitive beyond parity checks.\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal for a post\u2010selected LOQC Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate whose control amplitude is a continuous phase \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit.
