This echo network is interesting but essentially cascades standard swaps and parity checks.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty & Pytheus\u2010fit check:\n  A) No Pytheus target so far asked for a post\u2010selected Fredkin gate. A heralded Fredkin is a pure LOQC network transformation, not state generation. It yields a new routing primitive and directly ties into QPE by conditional path selection.\n  B) Too similar to SWITCH experiments, and SWITCH was earlier rejected as \u201cnot novel enough.\u201d\n  C) Reducible to sequential parity\u2010measurements\u2014supervisor wants a new primitive beyond parity checks.\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal for a post\u2010selected LOQC Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate whose control amplitude is a continuous phase \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit. It elevates entanglement swapping from state\u2010creation to photon\u2010routing: a single static network that conditionally swaps two modes based on a tunable phase, a brand\u2010new LOQC primitive never tackled by Pytheus.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:  \n\u2013 Uses only one single\u2010photon emitter (control qubit with phase \u03c6), two probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources (to supply the two target modes plus ancillas), beam splitters and static phase shifters, and four ancilla detectors for heralding.  \n\u2013 No cavities, no active feedback\u2014entirely a post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2013 Output is a two\u2010qubit gate (CSWAP) on abstract qubits A,B controlled by \u03c6; from this module one can build a photon\u2010routing QPE: routing the target photon k times through a \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f phase line by chaining identical Fredkin blocks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nDesign a heralded photonic Fredkin gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) on three abstract qubits C (control), A and B (targets):\n\n  U_CS\u2009WAP\u2009|c,a,b\u27e9 = |c\u27e9\u2297 \n       { |a,b\u27e9      if c=0  \n       { |b,a\u27e9       if c=1  \n\nThe control qubit C is a single photon whose |1\u27e9 amplitude carries a tunable phase \u03c6 (this phase is where you hook up the superconducting qubit). Upon two\u2010click heralding at ancilla detectors, the two input photons are consumed, and **a single output photon** emerges in mode 2 carrying the **sum** of the two phases.  This is neither state generation nor a gate on pre\u2010known computational basis states, but a new **quantum network transformation**: a \u201cphase\u2010sum\u201d device.\n\nVisual sketch (top \u2192 bottom):\n\n  Single-photon emitters:    [0]\u2500\u2500phase \u03c6\u2081\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                              [1]\u2500\u2500phase \u03c6\u2082\u2500\u2500\u253c\u2500\u2500\u25b6  \n  EPR pair source:            (modes 2\u21943)    \u2502    Network of  \n                                           \u2261 [BS + phase shifters]  \n  Detectors (herald):           [anc D\u2081=3] [anc D\u2082=4]  \n  Output qubit:                                      \u25b6 mode 2  \n\nKey settings for Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1]  (two input qubits)  \n  \u2022 one probabilistic EPR pair source between modes 2 and 3  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2, anc_detectors = [3,4]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [[2,0],[2,1],[3,0],[3,1]]  \n    (ensure no direct EPR half lands on an input detector)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: map the four-mode events  \n      \u201800?* \u2192 no herald\u2019,  \n      \u201801\u03d5\u2081 patterns + anc clicks \u2192 \u201csuccess even\u201d\u2019, etc.,  \n    so that the surviving amplitude on mode 2 is |0\u27e9 + e^{i(\u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082)}|1\u27e9.  \n\nConfig\u2010stub example:\n\n{'description': 'Heralded photonic phase\u2010adder: |+\u03c6\u2081>\u2297|+\u03c6\u2082>\u2192|+(\u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082)>',\n 'foldername':  'phase_adder',\n 'single_emitters': [0,1],\n 'pair_sources':    [[2,3]],\n 'removed_connections': [[2,0],[2,1],[3,0],[3,1]],\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'anc_detectors': [3,4],\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'loss_func':  'operator',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_unitary': [\n   # on input basis |i,j\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2297|00\u27e9\u2082\u2083, ancilla clicks at 3,4 should produce\n   # output in mode 2: amplitude \u221d \u03b4\u208di\u2295j=0\u208e\u00b71   +   \u03b4\u208di\u2295j=1\u208e\u00b7e^{i(\u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082)}\n ]}\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:  \n \u2022 This network is a **new LOQC primitive**\u2014a true \u201cphase adder\u201d at the single\u2010photon level\u2014never encoded as a target in Pytheus before.  \n \u2022 It directly fuses **superconducting\u2010encoded phases** \u03c6\u2081, \u03c6\u2082 into a purely photonic transformation.  \n \u2022 By feeding the output photon back through k modules with 2\u1d4f\u00b7\u03c6-shifters, one implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of QPE entirely via repeated phase addition, **no feedback or state generation** required.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to n-phase sums or even weighted sums (e.g. a\u00b7\u03c6\u2081 + b\u00b7\u03c6\u2082) by adjusting beam-splitter ratios and heralding."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Perfect state transfer on Cayley graphs over a group of order 8n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Mean-field and cumulant approaches to modelling organic polariton\n  physics\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: New Aspects of Optical Coherence and their Potential for Quantum\n  Technologies\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': This multi-qubit phase oracle is the building block of any quantum phase estimation circuit.  The unknown \u03b8 is programmed by a single variable phase shifter inside the ancilla interferometer\u2014this is where you would hook up a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output.  Upon a successful three-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the effective transformation on modes 0,1,2 is U.\n\nVisual sketch (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [EPR A\u2013A\u2032]   [EPR B\u2013B\u2032]   [EPR C\u2013C\u2032]\n  Linear network:  mix A\u2032,B\u2032,C\u2032 via beam splitters + three phase shifts \u03c6\u2081=\u03c6\u2082=\u03c6\u2083=\u03b8/3\n  Detectors:    [mode A=0] [mode B=1] [mode C=2] [anc D1=3] [anc D2=4] [anc D3=5]\n\nRemoved_connections:  \n  [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],  // A cannot come from wrong source into any ancilla  \n   [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],  // same for B  \n   [2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]  // and C  \n\nnum_anc = 3  \ndescription: \"Post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8) via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract): diag(1,1,1,1,1,1,1,e^{i\u03b8}) on the three-qubit basis.\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'C3-Rz-via-swapping',\n 'foldername':'C3Rz_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'target_quantum':['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111???'], # placeholders for 6-mode mapping\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5]\n}\n\nBy chaining this module for \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f with a small Fourier network on additional ancilla qubits, you immediately obtain a fully optical 2- or 3-bit quantum phase estimation subcircuit.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The three-qubit phase-oracle is simply the two-qubit entanglement-swapping CZ extended by another Bell pair and click detector. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; It uses one EPR source + two single\u2010photon sources + static linear optics + post\u2010selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit.  \n  B) The echo repeater is conceptually interesting but ultimately reduces to two sequential swaps plus a phase\u2010difference measurement\u2014too close to standard parity schemes.  \n  C) The modulo\u20104 parity switch is exotic but effectively just a doubled parity\u2010check network; it doesn\u2019t introduce a new interference\u2010based measurement beyond A).\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces a \u201csuperimposed Bell\u2010measurement\u201d LOQC primitive: instead of projecting onto one Bell basis at a time, the device post\u2010selectively implements a coherent superposition of two Bell measurements, extracting both sum\u2010 and difference\u2010phases of two unknown inputs simultaneously. The linear\u2010optical network is optimized so that, conditioned on exactly two clicks among the four ancilla detectors, the joint measurement projects A,B onto a superposition of two Bell bases:\n\n  Basis 1: |\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9 = (|00\u27e9\u00b1|11\u27e9)/\u221a2 \n  Basis 2: |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9 = (|01\u27e9\u00b1|10\u27e9)/\u221a2\n\nFour distinct click\u2010patterns (D\u2081&D\u2083, D\u2082&D\u2084, D\u2081&D\u2084, D\u2082&D\u2083) herald respectively:\n  \u2013 even\u2010sum bit: \u27e8\u03a6+|\u2192 \u201csum=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010sum  bit: \u27e8\u03a8+|\u2192 \u201csum=\u03c0\u201d  \n  \u2013 even\u2010diff bit:\u27e8\u03a6\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010diff  bit:\u27e8\u03a8\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=\u03c0\u201d\n\nThus in one heralded measurement we learn two bits: the parity of \u03c6A+\u03c6B and of \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B, implementing a two\u2010bit QPE subroutine on non\u2010commuting phase inputs.  \n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Inputs:      [Single\u2010photon A (mode 0)] \u2013 phase \u03c6A  \n               [Single\u2010photon B (mode 1)] \u2013 phase \u03c6B  \n  Source:      [EPR pair source: modes 2,3]  \n  Network:     [Beam splitters + fixed \u03c0/2 and 0 phases to be optimized]  \n  Detectors:   [anc D\u2081=4] [anc D\u2082=5] [anc D\u2083=6] [anc D\u2084=7]\n\nConstraints:\n  \u2013 removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]]  \n    (ensure no direct EPR half \u2192 input detours)  \n  \u2013 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2013 single_emitters = [0,1]  \n  \u2013 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Superimposed Bell\u2010measurement for sum/diff phase bits',\n 'foldername':'super-BSM_phaseQPE',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'single_emitters':[0,1],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]],\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5,6,7],\n 'target_quantum':[\n   #     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new LOQC primitive\u2014no simple Bell/GHZ scaling or concatenation of known gates\u2014that uses only Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical toolbox (pair sources, single-photon emitters, beam splitters, phase shifters, post-selection) and yet fuses a superconducting phase \u03c6 into a quantum network transformation.  My proposal is to realize a **heralded remote fractional-swap gate** between two spatially separated photonic qubits, with continuous swap angle \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit.  This \u201cremote beam-splitter\u201d or \u201cremote partial-SWAP\u201d is not just a teleportation-based CZ or Fredkin\u2014it\u2019s a new routing-and-mixing primitive that entangles and mixes two photons without direct interaction.  By chaining k of these static modules (each set to \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f), one implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation purely via photon routing, no feedback, and the phase \u03c6 feeds in directly from superconducting hardware.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a heralded, post-selected **remote fractional-swap gate** U(\u03c6) acting on two abstract photonic qubits in modes 0 and 1, defined on the single-photon subspace as\n\n\u2003U(\u03c6)|0,0\u27e9 = |0,0\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|1,1\u27e9 = |1,1\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|1,0\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u2009|1,0\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u2009|0,1\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|0,1\u27e9 = i\u2009sin\u03c6\u2009|1,0\u27e9 + cos\u03c6\u2009|0,1\u27e9.  \n\nThe continuous parameter \u03c6 is set by a single tunable phase shifter inside the ancilla network\u2014this is where a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output is wired in.  On a successful two-click herald (on the ancilla detectors), the inputs in modes 0&1 have undergone U(\u03c6) without ever meeting in the same beam splitter.  \n\nBy sequencing k such static modules\u2014each with the internal shifter set to 2\u1d4f\u03c6\u2014you directly realize the controlled\u2013U^(2\u1d4f) building blocks of quantum phase estimation on \u03c6, purely by repeated remote fractional-swap operations.  A final simple X\u2013basis measurement on one photon reads out the estimated phase bits, achieving QPE with a superconducting-programmed \u03c6 in a linear-optical network.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n Sources:      [EPR pair source: modes 2 \u2194 3]  \n Inputs:       [Single-photon mode 0] [Single-photon mode 1]  \n Network:      [Beam splitters + one phase shifter \u03c6 (to be optimized)]  \n Detectors:    [ancilla D\u2081=4] [ancilla D\u2082=5]  \n Outputs:      [mode 0_out] [mode 1_out]  \n\nConstraints:\n removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n num_anc = 2  \n single_emitters = [0,1]  \n anc_detectors = [4,5]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Heralded remote fractional\u2010swap U(phi)',\n 'foldername':'remote_frac_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':40,\n 'loss_func':'operator',   # target the 4\u00d74 block on one-photon subspace\n 'num_anc':2,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[0,1],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5]],\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5],\n 'target_unitary':[\n   # specify mapping on basis |00>,|01>,|10>,|11> to match U(phi)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 A brand\u2010new LOQC primitive\u2014an entanglement\u2010swap\u2013based **remote beamsplitter** / fractional-swap gate\u2014not reducible to a CZ or Fredkin.  \n \u2022 Continuous control phase \u03c6 is directly imported from a superconducting qubit, bridging microwave and photonic platforms.  \n \u2022 Chaining k modules with \u03c6\u21922\u1d4f\u03c6 implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation entirely by photon routing, without active feed-forward.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to higher-dimensional fractional exchanges and multi-photon routing networks for advanced quantum networks and distributed metrology."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While computing a nonlocal parity bit of two unknown remote phases via LOQC sounds interesting, this construction is essentially \u201centanglement\u2010swap both phases to the center and then interfere them\u201d\u2014a straightforward composition of two teleportation modules and a two\u2010mode interferometer. It mirrors the prior \u201cHeralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection,\u201d which already uses entanglement\u2010swapping and ancilla detection to compute a nonlinear function of two phase shifts. Shifting from a cosine-product to a parity-of-sum output does not introduce a fundamentally new measurement\u2010induced phenomenon or network topology.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes.     "output": "Thought: The \u201cremote fractional\u2010swap\u201d U(\u03c6) you propose is functionally identical to the heralded partial\u2010SWAP gate already present in the ensemble (\u201cHeralded Linear-Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling\u201d). Your scheme simply teleports the two qubits together via an EPR pair and then applies the known tunable beam-splitter-swap primitive. Chaining these modules for QPE is likewise a straightforward recombination of the same building block. There is no genuinely new multi-photon interference, routing paradox, or topology-protected feature beyond the existing partial-SWAP network.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To achieve true novelty, propose a fundamentally different LOQC primitive\u2014such as a non-Abelian fusion operation, a topological entanglement percolation effect, or a paradoxical superposition of network configurations\u2014that cannot be reduced to applying the well-known partial-SWAP gate via teleportation."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': That nonlocal gate is exactly the building block of QPE\u2019s controlled-U\u1d4f operations, so one can chain several of these networks (with different \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) to realize the QPE subroutine in a modular optical network.\n\n  B) A teleportation-based distributed phase sensor: each \u201csuperconducting qubit\u201d is abstracted as a local unknown phase \u03c6\u1d62 encoded onto a travelling photonic qubit; these modes are teleported via a central entanglement-swapping hub into a GHZ-like interferometer so that a multi-node QPE (measuring \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082+\u22ef) is performed in a single\u2010shot entangled measurement.\n\n  C) A measurement-based QPE: prepare a linear optical cluster-state via probabilistic pair sources and single photons, then perform local measurements that enact the sequence of controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) gates and an inverse quantum Fourier transform on photonic qubits; the superconducting computer is only invoked as the classical phase\u2010oracle that chooses measurement angles.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty check and Pytheus-compatibility:\n\n  A) No prior experiment in the list generates a nonlocal CZ by swapping. It\u2019s a pure quantum network + measurement effect (no state-prep target), uses only pair sources and linear optics, and generalizes to n-phase parity checks.  \n    B) Repeater-chain is also novel but becomes the trivial \u201cn-swap phase flip\u201d \u2192 multi-controlled phase gate, and supervisor flagged that as too simple.  \n    C) Two-ancilla QPE is just chaining CZ modules + a Bell analyzer; supervisor ruled out straightforward compositions.  \n  Step 3: Pick A.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has proposed using local entanglement-swapping modules at remote nodes to perform a nonlocal parity check of unknown phases. It fuses entanglement\u2010swapping with interferometric phase\u2010estimation in a way that can only be described as a new photonic \u201cphase-parity\u201d measurement primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible for Pytheus since it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two independent EPR pair sources at the remote nodes,  \n    \u2022 A central Bell-state analyzer (linear optics + beam splitters + ancilla detectors),  \n    \u2022 No active feed-forward, no cavities, only post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a nonlocal two-node phase-parity measurement: Alice and Bob each host a superconducting qubit whose unknown phase \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B is imprinted on a local photonic qubit via a path-phase shifter. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. The four click\u2010patterns simultaneously reveal the sum \u03c6A+\u03c6B and the difference \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B (i.e. two bits of phase information in one shot).  \n  B) A \u201cphase\u2010echo repeater\u201d chain where a photonic qubit picks up \u03c6 from a distant superconducting qubit, is entanglement\u2010swapped through two nodes with opposite phase\u2010shifter signs, and the ancilla\u2010heralded output cancels common noise while amplifying the target phase (a new LOQC echo\u2010measurement).  \n  C) A \u201ctwo\u2010branch parity switch\u201d that routes an input photon along two photonic paths conditioned on the unknown superconducting phase, then recombines them by entanglement\u2010swapping with an EPR pair, enabling a nondestructive modulo\u20104 phase check in one heralded click.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n  A) No existing Pytheus target uses a measurement basis that is itself a coherent superposition of two Bell bases. This is a new LOQC primitive that directly outputs two phase\u2010bits. It uses one EPR source + two single\u2010photon sources + static linear optics + post\u2010selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit.  \n  B) The echo repeater is conceptually interesting but ultimately reduces to two sequential swaps plus a phase\u2010difference measurement\u2014too close to standard parity schemes.  \n  C) The modulo\u20104 parity switch is exotic but effectively just a doubled parity\u2010check network; it doesn\u2019t introduce a new interference\u2010based measurement beyond A).\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces a \u201csuperimposed Bell\u2010measurement\u201d LOQC primitive: instead of projecting onto one Bell basis at a time, the device post\u2010selectively implements a coherent superposition of two Bell measurements, extracting both sum\u2010 and difference\u2010phases of two unknown inputs simultaneously. No prior experiment or Pytheus target has realized a measurement whose basis itself is a quantum superposition of different entanglement\u2010swapping bases.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it uses:\n  \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (the input qubits A,B carrying \u03c6A,\u03c6B),\n  \u2022 One probabilistic EPR pair source,\n  \u2022 A static linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and four ancilla detectors,\n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no state\u2010generation target\u2014only a quantum network transformation & measurement post\u2010selection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is your new Pytheus target proposal:\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single post\u2010selected LOQC device that takes two input photons A and B\u2014each has a path\u2010phase shift \u03c6A or \u03c6B programmed by a remote superconducting qubit\u2014and one EPR pair (modes C,D).  The linear\u2010optical network is optimized so that, conditioned on exactly two clicks among the four ancilla detectors, the joint measurement projects A,B onto a superposition of two Bell bases:\n\n  Basis 1: |\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9 = (|00\u27e9\u00b1|11\u27e9)/\u221a2 \n  Basis 2: |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9 = (|01\u27e9\u00b1|10\u27e9)/\u221a2\n\nFour distinct click\u2010patterns (D\u2081&D\u2083, D\u2082&D\u2084, D\u2081&D\u2084, D\u2082&D\u2083) herald respectively:\n  \u2013 even\u2010sum bit: \u27e8\u03a6+|\u2192 \u201csum=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010sum  bit: \u27e8\u03a8+|\u2192 \u201csum=\u03c0\u201d  \n  \u2013 even\u2010diff bit:\u27e8\u03a6\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010diff  bit:\u27e8\u03a8\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=\u03c0\u201d\n\nThus in one heralded measurement we learn two bits: the parity of \u03c6A+\u03c6B and of \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B, implementing a two\u2010bit QPE subroutine on non\u2010commuting phase inputs.  \n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Inputs:      [Single\u2010photon A (mode 0)] \u2013 phase \u03c6A  \n               [Single\u2010photon B (mode 1)] \u2013 phase \u03c6B  \n  Source:      [EPR pair source: modes 2,3]  \n  Network:     [Beam splitters + fixed \u03c0/2 and 0 phases to be optimized]  \n  Detectors:   [anc D\u2081=4] [anc D\u2082=5] [anc D\u2083=6] [anc D\u2084=7]\n\nConstraints:\n  \u2013 removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]]  \n    (ensure no direct EPR half \u2192 input detours)  \n  \u2013 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2013 single_emitters = [0,1]  \n  \u2013 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Superimposed Bell\u2010measurement for sum/diff phase bits',\n 'foldername':'super-BSM_phaseQPE',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'single_emitters':[0,1],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]],\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5,6,7],\n 'target_quantum':[\n   # This CSWAP is a new routing primitive\u2014rather than teleporting, it conditionally swaps two photonic modes.  Used repeatedly, it routes a target photon through successive phase\u2010oracle modules (\u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f) to build a QPE network by photon routing instead of many controlled\u2010phase gates.\n  B) A \u201ccoherent entanglement\u2010switch\u201d that superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swapping topologies (A\u2013C vs. A\u2013D) in one static network, controlled by a phase \u03c6 from a superconducting device\u2014an indefinite\u2010topology LOQC primitive.  Hard to implement unambiguously and may reduce to SWITCH, too similar to prior SWITCH proposals.\n  C) A multi\u2010port \u201cphase\u2010echo repeater\u201d that uses three entanglement\u2010swap nodes with alternating sign\u2010phase\u2010shifters to cancel common noise while amplifying the net unknown \u03c6 from a superconducting qubit.  This echo network is interesting but essentially cascades standard swaps and parity checks.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty & Pytheus\u2010fit check:\n  A) No Pytheus target so far asked for a post\u2010selected Fredkin gate. A heralded Fredkin is a pure LOQC network transformation, not state generation. It yields a new routing primitive and directly ties into QPE by conditional path selection.\n  B) Too similar to SWITCH experiments, and SWITCH was earlier rejected as \u201cnot novel enough.\u201d\n  C) Reducible to sequential parity\u2010measurements\u2014supervisor wants a new primitive beyond parity checks.\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal for a post\u2010selected LOQC Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate whose control amplitude is a continuous phase \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new LOQC primitive\u2014no simple Bell/GHZ scaling or concatenation of known gates\u2014that uses only Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical toolbox (pair sources, single-photon emitters, beam splitters, phase shifters, post-selection) and yet fuses a superconducting phase \u03c6 into a quantum network transformation.  My proposal is to realize a **heralded remote fractional-swap gate** between two spatially separated photonic qubits, with continuous swap angle \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit.  This \u201cremote beam-splitter\u201d or \u201cremote partial-SWAP\u201d is not just a teleportation-based CZ or Fredkin\u2014it\u2019s a new routing-and-mixing primitive that entangles and mixes two photons without direct interaction.  By chaining k of these static modules (each set to \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f), one implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation purely via photon routing, no feedback, and the phase \u03c6 feeds in directly from superconducting hardware.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a heralded, post-selected **remote fractional-swap gate** U(\u03c6) acting on two abstract photonic qubits in modes 0 and 1, defined on the single-photon subspace as\n\n\u2003U(\u03c6)|0,0\u27e9 = |0,0\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|1,1\u27e9 = |1,1\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|1,0\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u2009|1,0\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u2009|0,1\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|0,1\u27e9 = i\u2009sin\u03c6\u2009|1,0\u27e9 + cos\u03c6\u2009|0,1\u27e9.  \n\nThe continuous parameter \u03c6 is set by a single tunable phase shifter inside the ancilla network\u2014this is where a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output is wired in.  On a successful two-click herald (on the ancilla detectors), the inputs in modes 0&1 have undergone U(\u03c6) without ever meeting in the same beam splitter.  \n\nBy sequencing k such static modules\u2014each with the internal shifter set to 2\u1d4f\u03c6\u2014you directly realize the controlled\u2013U^(2\u1d4f) building blocks of quantum phase estimation on \u03c6, purely by repeated remote fractional-swap operations.  A final simple X\u2013basis measurement on one photon reads out the estimated phase bits, achieving QPE with a superconducting-programmed \u03c6 in a linear-optical network.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n Sources:      [EPR pair source: modes 2 \u2194 3]  \n Inputs:       [Single-photon mode 0] [Single-photon mode 1]  \n Network:      [Beam splitters + one phase shifter \u03c6 (to be optimized)]  \n Detectors:    [ancilla D\u2081=4] [ancilla D\u2082=5]  \n Outputs:      [mode 0_out] [mode 1_out]  \n\nConstraints:\n removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n num_anc = 2  \n single_emitters = [0,1]  \n anc_detectors = [4,5]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Heralded remote fractional\u2010swap U(phi)',\n 'foldername':'remote_frac_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':40,\n 'loss_func':'operator',   # specify mapping on basis |00>,|01>,|10>,|11> to match U(phi)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 A brand\u2010new LOQC primitive\u2014an entanglement\u2010swap\u2013based **remote beamsplitter** / fractional-swap gate\u2014not reducible to a CZ or Fredkin.  \n \u2022 Continuous control phase \u03c6 is directly imported from a superconducting qubit, bridging microwave and photonic platforms.  \n \u2022 Chaining k modules with \u03c6\u21922\u1d4f\u03c6 implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation entirely by photon routing, without active feed-forward.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to higher-dimensional fractional exchanges and multi-photon routing networks for advanced quantum networks and distributed metrology.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve true novelty, propose a fundamentally different LOQC primitive\u2014such as a non-Abelian fusion operation, a topological entanglement percolation effect, or a paradoxical superposition of network configurations\u2014that cannot be reduced to applying the well-known partial-SWAP gate via teleportation.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a truly novel LOQC primitive\u2014beyond Bell/GHZ analyzers, CZ/Fredkin blocks or simple state generation\u2014yet implementable by Pytheus\u2019s static linear\u2010optical toolkit (pair sources, single-photon emitters, beam splitters, phase shifters, post-selection).  The idea is to realize a **heralded photonic braiding gate** B(\u03c6) that enacts a non-Abelian exchange (a Yang\u2013Baxter R-matrix) on two dual-rail qubits, with the continuous braid angle \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit.  This B(\u03c6) is not expressible as a product of known LOQC primitives\u2014it\u2019s a new network transformation.  By chaining k such static braiding modules (each set to 2\u1d4f\u03c6), one directly implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation on \u03c6, purely via static photon routing and post-selection.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a **heralded photonic braiding gate** B(\u03c6) on two abstract qubits (modes 0 and 1).  In the computational basis {|00\u27e9,|01\u27e9,|10\u27e9,|11\u27e9}, B(\u03c6) implements the simplest non-trivial Yang\u2013Baxter R-matrix:\n\n \u2022 B(\u03c6)|00\u27e9 = e^{i\u03c6}|00\u27e9  \n \u2022 B(\u03c6)|11\u27e9 = e^{i\u03c6}|11\u27e9  \n \u2022 B(\u03c6)|01\u27e9 = |10\u27e9  \n \u2022 B(\u03c6)|10\u27e9 = |01\u27e9  \n\nHere \u03c6 is a continuous parameter set by an internal phase shifter, which in practice is driven by a remote superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output.  Upon a successful two-click herald on the ancilla detectors, the two input photons have been \u201cbraided\u201d without ever directly interacting\u2014this is a genuine non-Abelian routing/transformation primitive.\n\nBy chaining k identical B(2\u1d4f\u03c6) modules, one realizes the successive controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) operations needed for quantum phase estimation on \u03c6.  A final single-photon X-basis measurement reads out the estimated bits in a fully photonic network.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n Sources:       [Pair-source: modes 2\u21943]  \n Inputs:        [Single-photon mode 0]  [Single-photon mode 1]  \n Network:       [Beam-splitters + phase shifter \u03c6 (optimized)]  \n Detectors:     [ancilla D\u2081=4]  [ancilla D\u2082=5]  \n Outputs:       [mode 0_out]  [mode 1_out]  \n\nConstraints:\n removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n num_anc = 2  \n single_emitters = [0,1]  \n anc_detectors = [4,5]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Heralded photonic braiding gate B(phi) via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername':'braid_gate',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':60,\n 'ftol':1e-06,\n 'loss_func':'operator',\n 'num_anc':2,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':30,\n 'single_emitters':[0,1],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5]],\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5],\n 'target_unitary':[\n   '0000->e^{i\u03c6}0000',\n   '0100->0010',  # maps |01>\u2192|10>\n   '1000->0001',  # maps |10>\u2192|01>\n   '1111->e^{i\u03c6}1111'\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 Introduces a **non-Abelian braiding operation** as a new LOQC primitive, unlike any Bell, GHZ, CZ or Fredkin gate previously explored by Pytheus.  \n\u2022 The continuous braid angle \u03c6 is directly imported from a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase, linking microwave and optical quantum network domains.  \n\u2022 Chaining B(2\u1d4f\u03c6) modules implements quantum phase estimation of \u03c6 via static photon routing and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n\u2022 Generalizes to more complex braid-group representations (more modes) for topological photonic networks, anyonic simulation, and distributed metrology."
