LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum phase estimation\u201d with a \u201csuperconducting quantum computer\u201d in a genuinely new LOQC primitive\u2014no trivial Bell/GHZ scaling or just concatenating known gates, no state\u2010generation targets, only static linear optics, pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, and post\u2010selection:\n  A) A heralded fractional **3-cycle permutation** gate U\u2083(\u03c6) on three photonic qubits, which coherently \u201crotates\u201d the photon among modes 0\u21921\u21922\u21920 by an angle \u03c6 set by a superconducting qubit. By sequencing k modules with 2\u1d4f\u03c6, you directly implement the controlled\u2013U\u2083^(2\u1d4f) steps of QPE via photon routing\u2014no active feed\u2010forward.  \n  B) A **measurement\u2010induced network percolation** device: many EPR links form a mesh; two ancilla measurements controlled by \u03c6 determine which subnetwork percolates between two boundary qubits, yielding a nonlocal phase\u2010sum operation. (Hard to define cleanly and might reduce to parity\u2010check.)  \n  C) A **two\u2010channel entanglement\u2010superposition** switch: one static network superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swap graphs (A\u2013B vs. A\u2013C), with relative weight e^{i\u03c6}. Measurement heralds which superposed topology is enacted. (Very close to quantum SWITCH.)\n\nStep 2: Novelty & feasibility check:\n  A) No Pytheus target yet aims at a **3-cycle permutation gate** as a measurement\u2010heralded network primitive. It\u2019s not just a Fredkin or SWAP, but a new 3-way coherent routing.  \n  B) Percolation is intriguing but architecturally messy and likely reducible to known parity schemes.  \n  C) SWITCH\u2010like ideas have been proposed and rejected as \u201cnot novel.\u201d\n\nStep 3: Pick A.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces a **heralded fractional 3-cycle permutation**\u2014a static LOQC primitive that coherently rotates a single photon through three modes by an angle \u03c6. It cannot be decomposed into CZs, SWAPs or Fredkins without active feed\u2010forward, and it\u2019s never been targeted by Pytheus.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses:\n  \u2022 Three single\u2010photon emitters (the three input modes 0,1,2),  \n  \u2022 One probabilistic EPR\u2010pair source (to provide ancillas),  \n  \u2022 A static interferometer of beam splitters and one tunable phase shifter \u03c6,  \n  \u2022 Two ancilla detectors for heralding,  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no state\u2010generation goal\u2014just a 4\u00d74 unitary on the single\u2010photon subspace.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a heralded **fractional 3-cycle permutation** gate U\u2083(\u03c6) on three abstract photonic qubits (modes 0,1,2).  In the single\u2010photon subspace {|100\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|001\u27e9}, U\u2083(\u03c6) acts as\n  U\u2083(\u03c6)|100\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u00b7|100\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u00b7|010\u27e9  \n  U\u2083(\u03c6)|010\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u00b7|010\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u00b7|001\u27e9  \n  U\u2083(\u03c6)|001\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u00b7|001\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u00b7|100\u27e9  \nand leaves the zero\u2010 and three\u2010photon subspaces unchanged.  The continuous parameter \u03c6 is set by a single tunable phase\u2010shifter (the \u201coracle\u201d) linked to a superconducting qubit.  On a successful two\u2010click herald at the ancilla detectors, the input photon has been coherently cycled among the three modes by angle \u03c6 without direct multi\u2010mode overlap.\n\nBy chaining k copies of this static module\u2014each set to 2\u1d4f\u03c6\u2014you implement exactly the controlled\u2013U\u2083^(2\u1d4f) building blocks of a 3-level QPE algorithm on \u03c6, purely through photon routing.  A final single\u2010photon X\u2010basis measurement reads out the phase estimate bits.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:       [EPR pair: modes 3\u21944]\n  Inputs:        [Single\u2010photon mode 0] [Single\u2010photon mode 1] [Single\u2010photon mode 2]\n  Network:       [Beam splitters + phase shifter \u03c6 (to be optimized)]\n  Detectors:     [ancilla D\u2081=5] [ancilla D\u2082=6]\n  Outputs:       [mode 0_out] [mode 1_out] [mode 2_out]\n\nConstraints:\n  removed_connections = [[0,5],[0,6],[1,5],[1,6],[2,5],[2,6]]\n  num_anc = 2\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]\n  anc_detectors = [5,6]\n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Heralded fractional 3-cycle permutation U3(phi)',\n 'foldername':'fractional_3cycle',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'ftol':1e-06,\n 'loss_func':'operator',\n 'num_anc':2,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[0,1,2],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,5],[0,6],[1,5],[1,6],[2,5],[2,6]],\n 'anc_detectors':[5,6],\n 'target_unitary':[\n   # specify U\u2083(\u03c6) on the 3-dimensional single-photon subspace;\n   # identity on other photon-number subspaces\n ]\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 A brand\u2010new LOQC primitive\u2014measurement\u2010heralded fractional cycle of three modes\u2014never tackled before.  \n \u2022 Directly fuses a superconducting\u2010programmed \u03c6 into a photonic network transformation.  \n \u2022 Forms the kernel of an alternative QPE: conditional cycling instead of controlled\u2010phase gates.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to N-cycle gates and rich routing networks for distributed quantum metrology.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The measurement-heralded cyclic 3-swap is already realized; adding a tunable angle \u03c6 merely turns a static cycle into a trivial \u201cfractional\u201d interpolation. To be novel, propose a new multi-photon interference or topology-protected routing effect that cannot be reduced to a simple phase-shifter extension of an existing cyclic-swap network.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM.     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a truly new LOQC primitive\u2014one that cannot be reduced to chaining known gates or analyzers. The key is to make the measurement *itself* superpose two distinct entanglement\u2010swapping *topologies*, thereby creating a \u201cnetwork\u2010configuration superposition\u201d whose click outcome interferes different sums of remote phases \u03c6_i. This is not state generation but a fundamentally new quantum *network transformation* (a measurement\u2010induced superposition of graph\u2010connections). By imprinting superconducting\u2010qubit phases \u03c6\u2080\u2026\u03c6\u2083 on four photonic inputs and using four EPR sources plus beam splitters, the ancilla detection heralds either \u201cgraph A\u201d or \u201cgraph B,\u201d but because both paths cohere, the click statistics reveal cos[(\u03c6\u2080+\u03c6\u2081)\u2212(\u03c6\u2082+\u03c6\u2083)]. This merges nonlocal entanglement\u2010swapping, phase estimation, and network\u2010superposition in a way Pytheus can optimize (static linear optics, pair sources, single emitters, post\u2010selection).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a **heralded superposition of two entanglement\u2010swapping topologies** on four abstract photonic qubits A,B,C,D (modes 0\u20133), each carrying an unknown phase \u03c6\u2080\u2026\u03c6\u2083 from superconducting qubits. Using four independent EPR pair sources linking inputs to ancilla modes, a static beam\u2010splitter network mixes those ancilla modes. On a two\u2010click herald in the ancilla detectors, the device projects the four inputs onto a coherent superposition of:\n\n  \u2022 Graph G\u2081: A\u2013B and C\u2013D swaps  \n  \u2022 Graph G\u2082: A\u2013D and B\u2013C swaps  \n\nBecause the two graph\u2010swapping patterns interfere, the joint click\u2010probabilities reveal\n  P \u221d 1 + cos[(\u03c6\u2080+\u03c6\u2081) \u2212 (\u03c6\u2082+\u03c6\u2083)]\ni.e. a nonlocal interferometric readout of the difference between the sum of phases on one pairing vs. the other. This is neither state generation nor a simple analyzer\u2014it's a brand\u2010new LOQC primitive: **superposed network configurations via measurement\u2010induced entanglement routing**.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n Sources:      [Pair 0\u20134]  [Pair 1\u20135]  [Pair 2\u20136]  [Pair 3\u20137]\n Inputs:       modes 0(A,\u03c6\u2080), 1(B,\u03c6\u2081), 2(C,\u03c6\u2082), 3(D,\u03c6\u2083)\n Network:      mix ancilla modes 4\u20137 through optimized beam splitters & fixed phases\n Detectors:    ancilla D\u2081=4, D\u2082=5, D\u2083=6, D\u2084=7  \n Outputs:      modes 0_out,1_out,2_out,3_out pass through unchanged\n\nConstraints for Pytheus:\n removed_connections = [\n   [0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5],   # A,B only link to their own ancillas\n   [2,6],[2,7],[3,6],[3,7]    # C,D only link to theirs\n ]\n num_anc = 4\n single_emitters = []         # use probabilistic pair sources\n anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7]\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'Heralded superposition of two entanglement\u2010swapping graphs for nonlocal phase difference',\n 'foldername':'graph_superposition_phase',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,4],[1,5],[2,6],[2,7],[3,6],[3,7]],\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5,6,7],\n 'target_measurement':\n   { 'D1&D2 clicks \u2192 Graph G1',\n     'D3&D4 clicks \u2192 Graph G1',\n     'D1&D3 clicks \u2192 Graph G2',\n     'D2&D4 clicks \u2192 Graph G2' }\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 A *new* LOQC primitive: measurement\u2010induced superposition of network topologies, not reducible to known analyzers or gate chains.  \n \u2022 Extracts nonlocal phase interference between two different pairings of \u03c6\u2080\u2026\u03c6\u2083, achieving a \u201ctwo\u2010sum vs. sum\u201d phase\u2010difference estimation.  \n \u2022 Inputs \u03c6_i come directly from superconducting\u2010qubit phase oracles.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to larger graphs: superpose *any* two spanning\u2010tree entanglement\u2010swap patterns to measure arbitrary linear combinations of remote phases in one shot.\n\nThis target fits Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014static linear optics, pair sources, post\u2010selection\u2014and avoids state\u2010generation or dynamic feedback."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. Implemented in the Pytheus static post-selection framework, this battery-powered router converts non-unitary jump channels into a scalable tool for multi-branch entanglement distribution across quantum network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. This scheme infers the target \u0394N without disturbing modes A and D, providing a distributed QND observable extraction for syndrome readout and error checking across network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Implementation of a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe demonstrate a Blockade-Enabled 1D Entanglement Renormalization (BE-ER) Layer acting on an eight-qubit photonic chain, where nearest-neighbor probabilistic photon-pair sources feed cascaded Bell measurements as MERA-style disentanglers and isometries under a Rydberg-blockade\u2013inspired connectivity constraint.  This linear-optical network coarse-grains the input qubits into four renormalized outputs while exactly preserving the area-law entanglement profile, opening a new platform to study entanglement scaling under blockade-limited architectures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cascaded Partial-Bell Filters as a Passive Metamaterial for Heralded Entanglement\u2013Bandpass Filtering\n\nMini-Abstract: We present a four-mode linear-optical network comprising two back-to-back tunable partial-Bell analyzer modules that realizes the target heralded entanglement\u2013bandpass filtering entirely via passive optics and post-selection. By scanning the beam-splitter reflectivities and inter-module phase, the heralded success probability and output entanglement fidelity exhibit multi-peak resonance windows directly analogous to coupled nano-resonator band structures.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. No single pair source may emit to both mode-0 and mode-1 (enforced by removed_connections). Two ancillary photons are measured by Charlie to enact the gate.  Conditioned on a particular two-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the transformation on modes 0&1 is\n    |00>\u2192|00>,  |01>\u2192|01>,  |10>\u2192|10>,  |11>\u2192\u2212|11>.\nOnce you have this module, you can shift one internal phase shifter from \u03c0 to 2\u03c0/2\u1d4f and thereby build controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) gates.  Chaining these modules and adding a small Fourier-transform network on an ancilla register implements the 2-bit quantum phase estimation algorithm\u2014abstracted entirely in linear optics.\n\nVisual sketch (top to bottom):\n   Sources:    [Pair\u2010source A]   [Pair\u2010source B]\n   Network:    [Beam splitters + phase shifters to be optimized]\n   Detectors:  [mode 0] [mode 1] [anc det C1] [anc det C2]\n\nRemoved connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]]  \nnum_anc = 2  \ndescription: \"Post\u2010selected nonlocal CZ gate via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract) = diag(1,1,1,\u20131) on the two-qubit computational basis.  \nfamily_parameter \u03b8: allows replacing \u20131 by e^{i\u03b8} to yield controlled-R\u1dbb(\u03b8).  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Post\u2010selected nonlocal CZ via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'nonlocal_CZ',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],  # There is no genuinely new operational primitive or network effect beyond trivial module concatenation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is just the standard teleportation\u2010based CZ gate realized with two Bell pairs and ancilla clicks, and chaining it to perform QPE is a straightforward composition. Neither the gate construction nor the phase\u2010estimation application offers sufficient novelty over existing KLM/Gottesman\u2013Chuang schemes or prior photonic QPE experiments. Please propose a network or measurement effect that goes beyond simple teleportation\u2010gate modules.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposal for the next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nDesign a post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8), acting on photonic qubits A,B,C as\n   U|xyz\u27e9 = e^{i\u03b8\u00b7xyz}|xyz\u27e9,\ni.e. only |111\u27e9 picks up e^{i\u03b8}.  This multi-qubit phase oracle is the building block of any quantum phase estimation circuit.  The unknown \u03b8 is programmed by a single variable phase shifter inside the ancilla interferometer\u2014this is where you would hook up a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output.  Upon a successful three-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the effective transformation on modes 0,1,2 is U.\n\nVisual sketch (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [EPR A\u2013A\u2032]   [EPR B\u2013B\u2032]   [EPR C\u2013C\u2032]\n  Linear network:  mix A\u2032,B\u2032,C\u2032 via beam splitters + three phase shifts \u03c6\u2081=\u03c6\u2082=\u03c6\u2083=\u03b8/3\n  Detectors:    [mode A=0] [mode B=1] [mode C=2] [anc D1=3] [anc D2=4] [anc D3=5]\n\nRemoved_connections:  \n  [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],  // A cannot come from wrong source into any ancilla  \n   [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],  // same for B  \n   [2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]  // and C  \n\nnum_anc = 3  \ndescription: \"Post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8) via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract): diag(1,1,1,1,1,1,1,e^{i\u03b8}) on the three-qubit basis.\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'C3-Rz-via-swapping',\n 'foldername':'C3Rz_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'target_quantum':['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111???'], # placeholders for 6-mode mapping\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5]\n}\n\nBy chaining this module for \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f with a small Fourier network on additional ancilla qubits, you immediately obtain a fully optical 2- or 3-bit quantum phase estimation subcircuit.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal is nothing more than the straightforward generalization of the well\u2010known two\u2010qubit teleportation-based CZ gate to three qubits by adding one more Bell pair and ancilla detector. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap;     "output": "Thought: This proposal is effectively the same \u201csuperposed perfect\u2010matching entanglement swaps\u201d already explored in prior ensemble ideas (e.g. coherent superposition of AB&CD vs. AC&BD vs. AD&BC matchings). Restricting to only two matchings (AB&CD vs. AD&BC) and reading out a phase difference is just a pared-down version of that existing LOQC primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The measurement-induced superposition of entanglement-swap topologies on four nodes has already been proposed and studied. Simply reducing from three to two graph configurations and interpreting click patterns as a phase\u2010difference readout does not introduce a genuinely new network effect. To reach PRL-level novelty, please propose a primitive that cannot be mapped onto the known superposed-swap framework\u2014e.g. a higher-order network superposition, a truly non-Abelian fusion rule, or a topology-protected percolation phenomenon."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Perfect state transfer on Cayley graphs over a group of order 8n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Mean-field and cumulant approaches to modelling organic polariton\n  physics\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: New Aspects of Optical Coherence and their Potential for Quantum\n  Technologies\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': This diagonal unitary (1 on all basis states except e^{i\u03b8} on |111>) is the core multi-qubit phase oracle used in QPE circuits; the superconducting processor simply programs \u03b8 into a phase shifter.  \n  B) Teleport three unknown superconducting-encoded phases \u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082,\u03c6\u2083 onto three photonic qubits, perform a photonic Fourier interferometer that sums \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082+\u03c6\u2083 using entanglement swapping, and read out the sum via a multi-photon click pattern.  \n  C) Prepare a small linear-optical cluster (via probabilistic pair sources), then perform one-shot nonadaptive measurements that enact the entire 2-bit QFT plus controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) gates, where superconducting qubits set the measurement angles.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus-fit:\n  A) No prior Pytheus target builds a CCZ or C3-R\u1dbb gate by swapping three pairs. This multi-qubit phase oracle is the building block of any quantum phase estimation circuit.  The unknown \u03b8 is programmed by a single variable phase shifter inside the ancilla interferometer\u2014this is where you would hook up a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output.  Upon a successful three-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the effective transformation on modes 0,1,2 is U.\n\nVisual sketch (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [EPR A\u2013A\u2032]   [EPR B\u2013B\u2032]   [EPR C\u2013C\u2032]\n  Linear network:  mix A\u2032,B\u2032,C\u2032 via beam splitters + three phase shifts \u03c6\u2081=\u03c6\u2082=\u03c6\u2083=\u03b8/3\n  Detectors:    [mode A=0] [mode B=1] [mode C=2] [anc D1=3] [anc D2=4] [anc D3=5]\n\nRemoved_connections:  \n  [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],  // A cannot come from wrong source into any ancilla  \n   [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],  // same for B  \n   [2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]  // and C  \n\nnum_anc = 3  \ndescription: \"Post-selected three-qubit controlled-phase gate C3-R\u1dbb(\u03b8) via entanglement swapping\"  \ntarget_unitary (abstract): diag(1,1,1,1,1,1,1,e^{i\u03b8}) on the three-qubit basis.\n\nConfig stub:\n{'description':'C3-Rz-via-swapping',\n 'foldername':'C3Rz_swap',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'num_anc':3,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'target_quantum':['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111???'], # placeholders for 6-mode mapping\n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n 'number_resolving':True,\n 'anc_detectors':[3,4,5]\n}\n\nBy chaining this module for \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f with a small Fourier network on additional ancilla qubits, you immediately obtain a fully optical 2- or 3-bit quantum phase estimation subcircuit.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The three-qubit phase-oracle is simply the two-qubit entanglement-swapping CZ extended by another Bell pair and click detector. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; It uses one EPR source + two single\u2010photon sources + static linear optics + post\u2010selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit.  \n  B) The echo repeater is conceptually interesting but ultimately reduces to two sequential swaps plus a phase\u2010difference measurement\u2014too close to standard parity schemes.  \n  C) The modulo\u20104 parity switch is exotic but effectively just a doubled parity\u2010check network; it doesn\u2019t introduce a new interference\u2010based measurement beyond A).\n\nStep 3: Select A.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces a \u201csuperimposed Bell\u2010measurement\u201d LOQC primitive: instead of projecting onto one Bell basis at a time, the device post\u2010selectively implements a coherent superposition of two Bell measurements, extracting both sum\u2010 and difference\u2010phases of two unknown inputs simultaneously. The linear\u2010optical network is optimized so that, conditioned on exactly two clicks among the four ancilla detectors, the joint measurement projects A,B onto a superposition of two Bell bases:\n\n  Basis 1: |\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9 = (|00\u27e9\u00b1|11\u27e9)/\u221a2 \n  Basis 2: |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9 = (|01\u27e9\u00b1|10\u27e9)/\u221a2\n\nFour distinct click\u2010patterns (D\u2081&D\u2083, D\u2082&D\u2084, D\u2081&D\u2084, D\u2082&D\u2083) herald respectively:\n  \u2013 even\u2010sum bit: \u27e8\u03a6+|\u2192 \u201csum=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010sum  bit: \u27e8\u03a8+|\u2192 \u201csum=\u03c0\u201d  \n  \u2013 even\u2010diff bit:\u27e8\u03a6\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=0\u201d  \n  \u2013 odd\u2010diff  bit:\u27e8\u03a8\u2212|\u2192 \u201cdiff=\u03c0\u201d\n\nThus in one heralded measurement we learn two bits: the parity of \u03c6A+\u03c6B and of \u03c6A\u2013\u03c6B, implementing a two\u2010bit QPE subroutine on non\u2010commuting phase inputs.  \n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Inputs:      [Single\u2010photon A (mode 0)] \u2013 phase \u03c6A  \n               [Single\u2010photon B (mode 1)] \u2013 phase \u03c6B  \n  Source:      [EPR pair source: modes 2,3]  \n  Network:     [Beam splitters + fixed \u03c0/2 and 0 phases to be optimized]  \n  Detectors:   [anc D\u2081=4] [anc D\u2082=5] [anc D\u2083=6] [anc D\u2084=7]\n\nConstraints:\n  \u2013 removed_connections = [[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]]  \n    (ensure no direct EPR half \u2192 input detours)  \n  \u2013 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2013 single_emitters = [0,1]  \n  \u2013 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7]  \n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Superimposed Bell\u2010measurement for sum/diff phase bits',\n 'foldername':'super-BSM_phaseQPE',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'loss_func':'cr',\n 'single_emitters':[0,1],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,4],[0,5],[1,6],[1,7]],\n 'num_anc':4,\n 'anc_detectors':[4,5,6,7],\n 'target_quantum':[\n   # My proposal is to realize a **heralded remote fractional-swap gate** between two spatially separated photonic qubits, with continuous swap angle \u03c6 supplied by a superconducting qubit.  This \u201cremote beam-splitter\u201d or \u201cremote partial-SWAP\u201d is not just a teleportation-based CZ or Fredkin\u2014it\u2019s a new routing-and-mixing primitive that entangles and mixes two photons without direct interaction.  By chaining k of these static modules (each set to \u03c6\u00b72\u1d4f), one implements the controlled-U^(2\u1d4f) steps of quantum phase estimation purely via photon routing, no feedback, and the phase \u03c6 feeds in directly from superconducting hardware.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a heralded, post-selected **remote fractional-swap gate** U(\u03c6) acting on two abstract photonic qubits in modes 0 and 1, defined on the single-photon subspace as\n\n\u2003U(\u03c6)|0,0\u27e9 = |0,0\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|1,1\u27e9 = |1,1\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|1,0\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u2009|1,0\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u2009|0,1\u27e9,\u2003  \n\u2003U(\u03c6)|0,1\u27e9 = i\u2009sin\u03c6\u2009|1,0\u27e9 + cos\u03c6\u2009|0,1\u27e9.  \n\nThe continuous parameter \u03c6 is set by a single tunable phase shifter inside the ancilla network\u2014this is where a superconducting qubit\u2019s phase output is wired in. It is neither state generation nor a trivial scaling of Bell/GHZ analyzers, but a brand\u2010new \u201cphase\u2010adder\u201d transformation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want a heralded **photonic phase\u2010sum gate** that takes two single\u2010photon qubits A and B, each in the dual\u2010rail encoding\n   |\u03c8_A\u27e9 = |0\u27e9+e^{i\u03c6_A}|1\u27e9,\u2003|\u03c8_B\u27e9 = |0\u27e9+e^{i\u03c6_B}|1\u27e9,\nand outputs a single photonic qubit C carrying the sum\n   |\u03c8_C\u27e9 = |0\u27e9+e^{i(\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)}|1\u27e9,\nwhile the other modes are consumed in ancillas.  The continuous phases \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B are imprinted by two superconducting qubits under test.\n\nWe realize this by using two independent EPR\u2010pair sources and a static linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters + one internal phase shift (fixed to 0), plus two ancilla detectors.  On the heralding event (specific two\u2010click pattern), modes A and B have been \u201cmerged\u201d via entanglement\u2010swapping so that their phases add coherently onto a single output qubit C.  No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no cavities\u2014just post\u2013selected linear optics.\n\nVisual sketch (top \u2192 bottom):\n\n  EPR sources:    [Pair\u2010source 1: modes 2\u21943]   [Pair\u2010source 2: modes 4\u21945]  \n  Inputs:         mode 0 (dual\u2010rail A, \u03c6_A)   mode 1 (dual\u2010rail B, \u03c6_B)  \n  Network:        [optimized beam splitters + fixed phases]  \n  Detectors:      [anc D\u2081 = 6]  [anc D\u2082 = 7]  \n  Output:         mode 8 (dual\u2010rail C, carries \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)  \n\nNode labeling (abstract):\n  Inputs: 0,1  \n  EPR halves: 2,3 and 4,5  \n  Ancillas: 6,7  \n  Output: 8  \n\nRemoved connections (for pair\u2010sources\u2192ancillas):\n  [[0,6],[0,7],[1,6],[1,7]]  \n\nnum_anc = 2  \nsingle_emitters = []  # we use probabilistic pair sources  \nanc_detectors = [6,7]  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n{'description':'Heralded photonic phase\u2010adder \u03c6_C=\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername':'phase_adder',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':40,\n 'loss_func':'operator',     # match the 4\u00d74 block on the single-photon subspace\n 'num_anc':2,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,6],[0,7],[1,6],[1,7]],\n 'anc_detectors':[6,7],\n 'target_unitary':[\n   # on basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}_A \u2297 {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}_B \u2192 {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}_C:\n   #  |00> \u2192  |0>, \n   #  |01> \u2192  |1>\u00b7e^{i\u03c6_B}, \n   #  |10> \u2192  |1>\u00b7e^{i\u03c6_A}, \n   #  |11> \u2192  |1>\u00b7e^{i(\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)}\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 This is a brand\u2010new LOQC primitive: **phase\u2010addition via entanglement\u2010swapping**, not reducible to any prior Bell/GHZ or swap/Fredkin gate.  \n \u2022 It directly fuses two continuous superconducting phases \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B onto one photonic qubit, implementing \u03c6_C=\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B in a **single** heralded measurement.  \n \u2022 It uses only static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, and photon counting\u2014perfectly in Pytheus\u2019s wheelhouse.  \n \u2022 It generalizes to summing N phases by adding more EPR sources and ancilla detectors, enabling arbitrary linear combinations of remote superconducting\u2010qubit phases for distributed quantum phase estimation and metrology."

That nonlocal gate is exactly the building block of QPE\u2019s controlled-U\u1d4f operations, so one can chain several of these networks (with different \u03b8=2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) to realize the QPE subroutine in a modular optical network.\n\n  B) A teleportation-based distributed phase sensor: each \u201csuperconducting qubit\u201d is abstracted as a local unknown phase \u03c6\u1d62 encoded onto a travelling photonic qubit; these modes are teleported via a central entanglement-swapping hub into a GHZ-like interferometer so that a multi-node QPE (measuring \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082+\u22ef) is performed in a single\u2010shot entangled measurement.\n\n  C) A measurement-based QPE: prepare a linear optical cluster-state via probabilistic pair sources and single photons, then perform local measurements that enact the sequence of controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) gates and an inverse quantum Fourier transform on photonic qubits; the superconducting computer is only invoked as the classical phase\u2010oracle that chooses measurement angles.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty check and Pytheus-compatibility:\n\n  A) No prior experiment in the list generates a nonlocal CZ by swapping. Pytheus can optimize a small network of pair sources and beam splitters to post-select the CZ truth table. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n  B) Very interesting but more complex: teleports unknown phases (abstract states) then GHZ interferometry\u2014would amount to state generation of a GHZ-phase state, veering toward forbidden state generation.  \n  C) Measurement-based cluster QPE is conceptually heavy: Pytheus does not handle active adaptive measurements or large clusters easily; plus it leans on MBQC, which is close to state generation.\n\nStep 3: Select A as the most promising:  \n  \u2022 It\u2019s novel\u2014entanglement swapping used not to create entanglement but to enact a two-qubit controlled-phase unitary.  \n  \u2022 It is a crisp \u201cquantum network\u201d primitive of broad use (every QPE routine needs controlled-U gates).  \n  \u2022 Pytheus can search for a linear-optical arrangement of two Bell\u2010pair sources + ancillary detectors + beam splitters/phase shifters to implement post-selected CZ.  \n  \u2022 It requires no cavities, no feedback; it generalizes immediately to controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) by shifting the phase\u2010shifter settings. One can chain these modules into a full QPE network later.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because we have not seen any entanglement-swapping experiment that produces a nonlocal controlled-phase gate.  All prior examples either generate entangled states or perform teleportation/swap for state generation; none realize a gate as the primary outcome.\n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:  \n  \u2013 It uses only abstract qubits, probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It avoids state\u2010generation targets.  \n  \u2013 It defines a network (quantum transformation) that Pytheus can optimize.  \n  \u2013 It can be generalized to a family of controlled-phase gates with adjustable \u03b8, forming the core of a QPE network.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a post-selected linear-optical network implementing a nonlocal Controlled-Z gate between two photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1), using two independent Bell\u2010pair sources and entanglement swapping.  No single pair source may emit to both mode-0 and mode-1 (enforced by removed_connections). Two ancillary photons are measured by Charlie to enact the gate.  Conditioned on a particular two-fold click at the ancilla detectors, the transformation on modes 0&1 is\n    |00>\u2192|00>,  |01>\u2192|01>,  |10>\u2192|10>,  |11>\u2192\u2212|11>.\nOnce you have this module, you can shift one internal phase shifter from \u03c0 to 2\u03c0/2\u1d4f and thereby build controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) gates. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. On a two\u2010click herald in the ancilla detectors, the device projects the four inputs onto a coherent superposition of:\n\n  \u2022 Graph G\u2081: A\u2013B and C\u2013D swaps  \n  \u2022 Graph G\u2082: A\u2013D and B\u2013C swaps  \n\nBecause the two graph\u2010swapping patterns interfere, the joint click\u2010probabilities reveal\n  P \u221d 1 + cos[(\u03c6\u2080+\u03c6\u2081) \u2212 (\u03c6\u2082+\u03c6\u2083)]\ni.e. a nonlocal interferometric readout of the difference between the sum of phases on one pairing vs. the other.     "output": "Here is a genuinely new LOQC measurement primitive for Pytheus\u2014no trivial Bell/GHZ scaling, no state\u2010prep target, only static linear optics + post\u2010selection\u2014capable of serving as the final measurement in a hybrid photonic\u2013superconducting quantum phase estimation:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a **post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical analyzer of the three\u2010qubit symmetric group S\u2083 irreducible representations**.  Three photonic qubits (modes 0,1,2) each pick up an unknown phase \u03c6\u2080,\u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082 (encoded by superconducting phase modulators).  The network must project the joint 2\u00b3\u2010dim Hilbert space onto the three S\u2083\u2010irreps:\n\n  \u2022 1-D trivial (fully symmetric) subspace  \n  \u2022 1-D sign (fully antisymmetric) subspace  \n  \u2022 2-D standard representation (mixed symmetry)  \n\nConditioned on distinct two-click patterns in two ancilla detectors, the device tells you which irrep the inputs occupy.  Because the three input phases enter as e^{i\u03c6_j} weightings in the symmetric/antisymmetric sums, this measurement immediately reveals functions like \u03c6\u2080+\u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082 (mod 2\u03c0) vs. parity combinations, and can be chained into a full quantum phase estimation routine by replacing \u03c6_j\u21922\u1d4f\u03c6_j for successive precision bits.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [Pair-source between ancilla modes 3\u21944]  \n  Inputs:       [Single photons in modes 0,1,2 each with phase \u03c6\u2080,\u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082]  \n  Network:      [Beam splitters + phase shifters \u2013 to be optimized by Pytheus]  \n  Detectors:    [ancilla D\u2081=3] [ancilla D\u2082=4]  \n  Outputs:      (no \u201coutput\u201d modes; success is heralded by a click pair)\n\nConstraints for Pytheus:\n  removed_connections = [[0,3],[0,4],[1,3],[1,4],[2,3],[2,4]]   # LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to meaningfully connect \u201cquantum phase estimation\u201d with \u201csuperconducting quantum computer\u201d in a pure photonic-network Pytheus can optimize:\n    A) A distributed phase-parity measurement: use two local entanglement-swapping nodes (with their own EPR sources) to imprint unknown superconducting phases \u03c6\u2081,\u03c6\u2082 onto flying photons, then perform a central Bell-measurement that heralds the parity bit of \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082.  \n    B) A repeater-chain phase accumulator: send one photon through a chain of entanglement-swap stations, each station\u2019s Bell-measurement contains a local phase shifter tied to a superconducting qubit; the final heralding probability encodes the sum of all phases.  \n    C) A two-ancilla QPE gadget: prepare two ancilla photons in |+\u3009, enact controlled-R\u1dbb(2\u03c0/2\u1d4f) on each via entanglement-swapping with a single target phase-shifted photon, then post-selected Bell-analyze the ancillas to read out the two bits.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus fit:\n    A) No previous Pytheus target measures phase parity via entanglement swapping. It\u2019s a pure quantum network + measurement effect (no state-prep target), uses only pair sources and linear optics, and generalizes to n-phase parity checks.  \n    B) Repeater-chain is also novel but becomes the trivial \u201cn-swap phase flip\u201d \u2192 multi-controlled phase gate, and supervisor flagged that as too simple.  \n    C) Two-ancilla QPE is just chaining CZ modules + a Bell analyzer; supervisor ruled out straightforward compositions.  \n  Step 3: Pick A.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has proposed using local entanglement-swapping modules at remote nodes to perform a nonlocal parity check of unknown phases. It fuses entanglement\u2010swapping with interferometric phase\u2010estimation in a way that can only be described as a new photonic \u201cphase-parity\u201d measurement primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible for Pytheus since it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two independent EPR pair sources at the remote nodes,  \n    \u2022 A central Bell-state analyzer (linear optics + beam splitters + ancilla detectors),  \n    \u2022 No active feed-forward, no cavities, only post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a nonlocal two-node phase-parity measurement: Alice and Bob each host a superconducting qubit whose unknown phase \u03c6_A, \u03c6_B is imprinted on a local photonic qubit via a path-phase shifter. Using two independent EPR pair sources at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s sites, each photonic qubit is entangled and then subjected to a Bell-measurement at a central station\u2014this is two spatially separated entanglement-swapping modules. The two swapped photons are then jointly Bell-analyzed in a third photonic network, whose click pattern (one of two distinct two-fold coincidences) heralds the parity bit Parity = floor((\u03c6_A+\u03c6_B)/\u03c0) \u2208 {0,1}.\n\nIn other words, the entire network realizes a measurement that outputs \u201ceven\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u22480 mod 2\u03c0, \u201codd\u201d if \u03c6_A+\u03c6_B\u2248\u03c0 mod 2\u03c0, without ever bringing Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits together. This parity check is a new LOQC primitive: a measurement-induced phase parity gate.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Alice\u2019s station:    [EPR source 1: modes A, A\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_A on mode A]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by A\u2032]\n\n  Bob\u2019s station:      [EPR source 2: modes B, B\u2032]  \n                      [Phase shift \u03c6_B on mode B]  \n                      [Bell-measurement optics at central node fed by B\u2032]\n\n  Central parity analyzer:\n                      [Interferometer mixing the two swapped photons]  \n                      [Beam splitters + fixed phases \u2192 two ancilla detectors C0,C1]\n\nWhen Charlie registers a click at C0 (and no click at C1) we infer \u201ceven\u201d parity; a click at C1 signals \u201codd.\u201d  \n\nPytheus config stub:\n\n{'description': 'Distributed phase\u2010parity measurement via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'phase_parity_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,                    # the two ancilla detectors at central node\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 20,\n 'single_emitters': [],           # we use probabilistic pair sources\n 'removed_connections': [         # ensure no source straddles Alice/Bob output and central ancilla\n   [0,2],[0,3],  # mode 0=A\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n   [1,2],[1,3]   # mode 1=B\u2032 cannot go to C0,C1 directly\n ],\n 'anc_detectors': [2,3],          # indices of C0,C1\n 'target_quantum': [               # specify \u201ceven\u201d vs \u201codd\u201d click patterns\n   '0000',  # A,B feed into swap; C0 clicks (even)\n   '0011'   # A,B feed into swap; C1 clicks (odd)\n ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a fundamentally new quantum network measurement that computes the parity of two unknown remote phases using only LOQC and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 It fits squarely in the entanglement-swapping/teleportation toolbox but goes beyond state generation: it\u2019s a nonlocal phase\u2010computation primitive.  \n  \u2013 It generalizes immediately to n-phase parity checks or even multi-bit modular sums by adding more EPR sources and ancilla analyzers.  \n\nHooking up the phase shifters to superconducting qubit outputs makes this a hybrid photonic-superconducting demonstration of distributed quantum phase estimation (the simplest \u201c1\u2010bit\u201d QPE) in a quantum network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively two sequential teleportation steps plus a standard two-photon interference for parity readout, closely paralleling existing remote phase-sensor schemes. It\u2019s not just a Fredkin or SWAP, but a new 3-way coherent routing.  \n  B) Percolation is intriguing but architecturally messy and likely reducible to known parity schemes.  \n  C) SWITCH\u2010like ideas have been proposed and rejected as \u201cnot novel.\u201d\n\nStep 3: Pick A.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces a **heralded fractional 3-cycle permutation**\u2014a static LOQC primitive that coherently rotates a single photon through three modes by an angle \u03c6. It cannot be decomposed into CZs, SWAPs or Fredkins without active feed\u2010forward, and it\u2019s never been targeted by Pytheus.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses:\n  \u2022 Three single\u2010photon emitters (the three input modes 0,1,2),  \n  \u2022 One probabilistic EPR\u2010pair source (to provide ancillas),  \n  \u2022 A static interferometer of beam splitters and one tunable phase shifter \u03c6,  \n  \u2022 Two ancilla detectors for heralding,  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no state\u2010generation goal\u2014just a 4\u00d74 unitary on the single\u2010photon subspace.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for your next Pytheus target:\n\nExplanation:\nWe ask Pytheus to design a heralded **fractional 3-cycle permutation** gate U\u2083(\u03c6) on three abstract photonic qubits (modes 0,1,2).  In the single\u2010photon subspace {|100\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|001\u27e9}, U\u2083(\u03c6) acts as\n  U\u2083(\u03c6)|100\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u00b7|100\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u00b7|010\u27e9  \n  U\u2083(\u03c6)|010\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u00b7|010\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u00b7|001\u27e9  \n  U\u2083(\u03c6)|001\u27e9 = cos\u03c6\u00b7|001\u27e9 + i\u2009sin\u03c6\u00b7|100\u27e9  \nand leaves the zero\u2010 and three\u2010photon subspaces unchanged.  The continuous parameter \u03c6 is set by a single tunable phase\u2010shifter (the \u201coracle\u201d) linked to a superconducting qubit.  On a successful two\u2010click herald at the ancilla detectors, the input photon has been coherently cycled among the three modes by angle \u03c6 without direct multi\u2010mode overlap.\n\nBy chaining k copies of this static module\u2014each set to 2\u1d4f\u03c6\u2014you implement exactly the controlled\u2013U\u2083^(2\u1d4f) building blocks of a 3-level QPE algorithm on \u03c6, purely through photon routing.  A final single\u2010photon X\u2010basis measurement reads out the phase estimate bits.\n\nVisual sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:       [EPR pair: modes 3\u21944]\n  Inputs:        [Single\u2010photon mode 0] [Single\u2010photon mode 1] [Single\u2010photon mode 2]\n  Network:       [Beam splitters + phase shifter \u03c6 (to be optimized)]\n  Detectors:     [ancilla D\u2081=5] [ancilla D\u2082=6]\n  Outputs:       [mode 0_out] [mode 1_out] [mode 2_out]\n\nConstraints:\n  removed_connections = [[0,5],[0,6],[1,5],[1,6],[2,5],[2,6]]\n  num_anc = 2\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]\n  anc_detectors = [5,6]\n\nConfig stub for Pytheus:\n{'description':'Heralded fractional 3-cycle permutation U3(phi)',\n 'foldername':'fractional_3cycle',\n 'bulk_thr':0.01,\n 'edges_tried':50,\n 'ftol':1e-06,\n 'loss_func':'operator',\n 'num_anc':2,\n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples':20,\n 'single_emitters':[0,1,2],\n 'removed_connections':[[0,5],[0,6],[1,5],[1,6],[2,5],[2,6]],\n 'anc_detectors':[5,6],\n 'target_unitary':[\n   # specify U\u2083(\u03c6) on the 3-dimensional single-photon subspace;\n   # identity on other photon-number subspaces\n ]\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 A brand\u2010new LOQC primitive\u2014measurement\u2010heralded fractional cycle of three modes\u2014never tackled before.  \n \u2022 Directly fuses a superconducting\u2010programmed \u03c6 into a photonic network transformation.  \n \u2022 Forms the kernel of an alternative QPE: conditional cycling instead of controlled\u2010phase gates.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to N-cycle gates and rich routing networks for distributed quantum metrology.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The measurement-heralded cyclic 3-swap is already realized; adding a tunable angle \u03c6 merely turns a static cycle into a trivial \u201cfractional\u201d interpolation.
